title: The third Part of Henry the Sixt, with the death of the Duke of Yorke from Mr. William Shakespeares comedies, histories, & tragedies. Published according to the true originall copies.

lines.text: Tyre on the flesh of me, and of my Sonne.

lines.speaker: Henry.
lines.text: The losse of those three Lords torments my heart:

lines.speaker: Henry.
lines.text: Ile write vnto them, and entreat them faire;

lines.speaker: Henry.

lines.text: And I, I hope, shall reconcile them all.

lines.speaker: Richard.
lines.text: Brother, though I bee youngest, giue mee

lines.text: No, I can better play the Orator.

lines.speaker: Mount.

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: Why how now Sonnes, and Brother, at a strife?

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: What is your Quarrell? how began it first?

lines.speaker: Edward.
lines.text: No Quarrell, but a slight Contention.

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: About what?

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: About that which concernes your Grace and vs,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: The Crowne of England, Father, which is yours.

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: Mine Boy? not till King {% italic: Henry %} be dead.

lines.speaker: Richard.
lines.text: Your Right depends not on his life, or death.

lines.speaker: Edward.
lines.text: Now you are Heire, therefore enioy it now:

lines.speaker: Edward.
lines.text: By giuing the House of {% italic: Lancaster %} leaue to breathe,

lines.speaker: Edward.
lines.text: It will out‑runne you, Father, in the end.

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: I tooke an Oath, that hee should quietly

lines.speaker: Edward.
lines.text: But for a Kingdome any Oath may be broken:

lines.speaker: Edward.
lines.text: I would breake a thousand Oathes, to reigne one yeere.

lines.speaker: Richard.
lines.text: No: God forbid your Grace should be for­

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: I shall be, if I clayme by open Warre.

lines.speaker: Richard.
lines.text: Ile proue the contrary, if you'le heare mee

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: Thou canst not, Sonne: it is impossible.

lines.speaker: Richard.
lines.text: An Oath is of no moment, being not tooke

lines.speaker: Richard.
lines.text: Before a true and lawfull Magistrate,

lines.speaker: Richard.
lines.text: That hath authoritie ouer him that sweares.

lines.speaker: Richard.
lines.text: {% italic: Henry %} had none, but did vsurpe the place.

lines.speaker: Richard.
lines.text: Then seeing 'twas he that made you to depose,

lines.speaker: Richard.
lines.text: Your Oath, my Lord, is vaine and friuolous.

lines.speaker: Richard.
lines.text: Therefore to Armes: and Father doe but thinke,

lines.speaker: Richard.
lines.text: How sweet a thing it is to weare a Crowne,

lines.speaker: Richard.
lines.text: Within whose Circuit is {% italic: Elizium %},

lines.speaker: Richard.
lines.text: And all that Poets faine of Blisse and Ioy.

lines.speaker: Richard.
lines.text: Why doe we linger thus? I cannot rest,

lines.speaker: Richard.
lines.text: Vntill the White Rose that I weare, be dy'de

lines.speaker: Richard.
lines.text: Euen in the luke‑warme blood of {% italic: Henries %} heart.

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: {% italic: Richard %} ynough: I will be King, or dye.

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: Brother, thou shalt to London presently,

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: And whet on {% italic: Warwick %} to this Enterprise.

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: Thou {% italic: Richard %} shalt to the Duke of Norfolke,

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: And tell him priuily of our intent.

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: You {% italic: Edward %} shall vnto my Lord {% italic: Cobham %},

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: With whom the Kentishmen will willingly rise.

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: In them I trust: for they are Souldiors,

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: Wittie, courteous, liberall, full of spirit.

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: While you are thus imploy'd, what resteth more?

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: But that I seeke occasion how to rise,

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: And yet the King not priuie to my Drift,

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: Nor any of the House of {% italic: Lancaster %}.

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: But stay, what Newes? Why comm'st thou in such

lines.speaker: Gabriel.
lines.text: The Queene,

lines.speaker: Gabriel.
lines.text: With all the Northerne Earles and Lords,

lines.speaker: Gabriel.
lines.text: Intend here to besiege you in your Castle.

lines.speaker: Gabriel.
lines.text: She is hard by, with twentie thousand men:

lines.speaker: Gabriel.
lines.text: And therefore fortifie your Hold, my Lord.

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: I, with my Sword.

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: What? think'st thou, that we feare them?

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: {% italic: Edward %} and {% italic: Richard %}, you shall stay with me,

lines.speaker: Yorke.

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: Whom we haue left Protectors of the King,

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: With powrefull Pollicie strengthen themselues,

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: And trust not simple {% italic: Henry %}, nor his Oathes.

lines.text: Brother, I goe: Ile winne them, feare it not.

lines.text: And thus most humbly I doe take my leaue.

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: Sir {% italic: Iohn %}, and Sir {% italic: Hugh Mortimer %}, mine Vnckles,

lines.speaker: Yorke.

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: The Armie of the Queene meane to besiege vs.

lines.text: Shee shall not neede, wee'le meete her in the

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: What, with fiue thousand men?

lines.speaker: Richard.
lines.text: A Woman's generall: what should we feare?

lines.speaker: Edward.
lines.text: I heare their Drummes:

lines.speaker: Edward.
lines.text: Let's set our men in order,

lines.speaker: Edward.
lines.text: And issue forth, and bid them Battaile straight.

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: Fiue men to twentie: though the oddes be great,

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: I doubt not, Vnckle, of our Victorie.

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: Many a Battaile haue I wonne in France,

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: When as the Enemie hath beene tenne to one:

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: Why should I not now haue the like successe?

lines.speaker: Rutland.
lines.text: Ah, whither shall I flye, to scape their hands?

lines.speaker: Rutland.
lines.text: Ah Tutor, looke where bloody {% italic: Clifford %} comes.

lines.speaker: Clifford.
lines.text: Chaplaine away, thy Priesthood saues thy life.

lines.speaker: Clifford.
lines.text: As for the Brat of this accursed Duke,

lines.speaker: Clifford.
lines.text: Whose Father slew my Father, he shall dye.

lines.speaker: Tutor.
lines.text: And I, my Lord, will beare him company.

lines.speaker: Clifford.
lines.text: Souldiers, away with him.

lines.speaker: Tutor.
lines.text: Ah {% italic: Clifford %}, murther not this innocent Child,

lines.speaker: Tutor.
lines.text: Least thou be hated both of God and Man.

lines.speaker: Clifford.
lines.text: How now? is he dead alreadie?

lines.speaker: Clifford.
lines.text: Or is it feare, that makes him close his eyes?

lines.speaker: Clifford.
lines.text: Ile open them.

lines.speaker: Rutland.
lines.text: So looks the pent‑vp Lyon o're the Wretch,

lines.speaker: Rutland.
lines.text: That trembles vnder his deuouring Pawes:

lines.speaker: Rutland.
lines.text: And so he walkes, insulting o're his Prey,

lines.speaker: Rutland.
lines.text: And so he comes, to rend his Limbes asunder.

lines.speaker: Rutland.
lines.text: Ah gentle {% italic: Clifford %}, kill me with thy Sword,

lines.speaker: Rutland.
lines.text: And not with such a cruell threatning Looke.

lines.speaker: Rutland.
lines.text: Sweet {% italic: Clifford %} heare me speake, before I dye:

lines.speaker: Rutland.
lines.text: I am too meane a subiect for thy Wrath,

lines.speaker: Rutland.
lines.text: Be thou reueng'd on men, and let me liue.

lines.speaker: Clifford.
lines.text: In vaine thou speak'st, poore Boy:

lines.speaker: Clifford.
lines.text: My Fathers blood hath stopt the passage

lines.speaker: Clifford.
lines.text: Where thy words should enter.

lines.speaker: Rutland.
lines.text: Then let my Fathers blood open it againe,

lines.speaker: Rutland.
lines.text: He is a man, and {% italic: Clifford %} cope with him.

lines.speaker: Clifford.
lines.text: Had I thy Brethren here, their liues and thine

lines.speaker: Clifford.
lines.text: Were not reuenge sufficient for me:

lines.speaker: Clifford.
lines.text: No, if I digg'd vp thy fore‑fathers Graues,

lines.speaker: Clifford.
lines.text: And hung their rotten Coffins vp in Chaynes,

lines.speaker: Clifford.
lines.text: It could not slake mine ire, nor ease my heart.

lines.speaker: Clifford.
lines.text: The sight of any of the House of {% italic: Yorke %},

lines.speaker: Clifford.
lines.text: Is as a furie to torment my Soule:

lines.speaker: Clifford.
lines.text: And till I root out their accursed Line,

lines.speaker: Clifford.
lines.text: And leaue not one aliue, I liue in Hell.

lines.speaker: Clifford.
lines.text: Therefore‑‑‑

lines.speaker: Rutland.
lines.text: Oh let me pray, before I take my death:

lines.speaker: Rutland.
lines.text: To thee I pray; sweet {% italic: Clifford %} pitty me.

lines.speaker: Clifford.
lines.text: Such pitty as my Rapiers point affords.

lines.speaker: Rutland.
lines.text: I neuer did thee harme: why wilt thou slay

lines.speaker: Clifford.
lines.text: Thy Father hath.

lines.speaker: Rutland.
lines.text: But 'twas ere I was borne.

lines.speaker: Rutland.
lines.text: Thou hast one Sonne, for his sake pitty me,

lines.speaker: Rutland.
lines.text: Least in reuenge thereof, sith God is iust,

lines.speaker: Rutland.
lines.text: He be as miserably slaine as I.

lines.speaker: Rutland.
lines.text: Ah, let me liue in Prison all my dayes,

lines.speaker: Rutland.
lines.text: And when I giue occasion of offence,

lines.speaker: Rutland.
lines.text: Then let me dye, for now thou hast no cause.

lines.speaker: Clifford.
lines.text: No cause? thy Father slew my Father: there­

lines.speaker: Rutland.
lines.text: Dis faciant laudis summa sit ista tuæ.

lines.speaker: Clifford.
lines.text: {% italic: Plantagenet %}, I come {% italic: Plantagenet: %}

lines.speaker: Clifford.
lines.text: Shall rust vpon my Weapon, till thy blood

lines.speaker: Clifford.
lines.text: Congeal'd with this, doe make me wipe off both.

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: The Army of the Queene hath got the field:

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: My Vnckles both are slaine, in rescuing me;

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: And all my followers, to the eager foe

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: Turne back, and flye, like Ships before the Winde,

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: Or Lambes pursu'd by hunger‑starued Wolues.

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: My Sonnes, God knowes what hath bechanced them:

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: But this I know, they haue demean'd themselues

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: Like men borne to Renowne, by Life or Death.

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: Three times did {% italic: Richard %} make a Lane to me,

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: And thrice cry'de, Courage Father, fight it out:

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: And full as oft came {% italic: Edward %} to my side,

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: With Purple Faulchion, painted to the Hilt,

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: In blood of those that had encountred him:

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: And when the hardyest Warriors did retyre,

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: {% italic: Richard %} cry'de, Charge, and giue no foot of ground,

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: And cry'de, A Crowne, or else a glorious Tombe,

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: A Scepter, or an Earthly Sepulchre.

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: With this we charg'd againe: but out alas,

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: We bodg'd againe, as l haue seene a Swan

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: With bootlesse labour swimme against the Tyde,

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: And spend her strength with ouer‑matching Waues.

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: Ah hearke, the fatall followers doe pursue,

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: And I am faint, and cannot flye their furie:

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: And were I strong, I would not shunne their furie.

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: The Sands are numbred, that makes vp my Life,

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: Here must I stay, and here my Life must end.

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: Come bloody {% italic: Clifford %}, rough {% italic: Northumberland %},

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: I dare your quenchlesse furie to more rage;

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: I am your Butt, and I abide your Shot.

lines.speaker: Northumb.
lines.text: Yeeld to our mercy, proud {% italic: Plantagenet %}.

lines.speaker: Clifford.
lines.text: I, to such mercy, as his ruthlesse Arme

lines.text: With downe‑right payment, shew'd vnto my Father.

lines.speaker: Clifford.
lines.text: And made an Euening at the Noone‑tide Prick.

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: My ashes, as the Phœnix, may bring forth

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: And in that hope, I throw mine eyes to Heauen,

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: Scorning what ere you can afflict me with.

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: Why come you not? what, multitudes, and feare?

lines.text: So Cowards fight, when they can flye no further,

lines.speaker: Cliff.

lines.speaker: Cliff.
lines.text: Breathe out Inuectiues 'gainst the Officers.

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: Oh {% italic: Clifford %}, but bethinke thee once againe,

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: And in thy thought ore‑run my former time:

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: And if thou canst, for blushing, view this face,

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: And bite thy tongue, that slanders him with Cowardice,

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: Whose frowne hath made thee faint and flye ere this.

lines.speaker: Clifford.
lines.text: I will not bandie with thee word for word,

lines.speaker: Clifford.
lines.text: But buckler with thee blowes twice two for one.

lines.speaker: Queene.
lines.text: Hold valiant {% italic: Clifford %}, for a thousand causes

lines.speaker: Queene.
lines.text: I would prolong a while the Traytors Life:

lines.speaker: Queene.
lines.text: Wrath makes him deafe; speake thou {% italic: Northumberland %}.

lines.speaker: Northumb.
lines.text: Hold {% italic: Clifford %}, doe not honor him so much,

lines.speaker: Northumb.
lines.text: To prick thy finger, though to wound his heart.

lines.speaker: Northumb.
lines.text: What valour were it, when a Curre doth grinne,

lines.speaker: Northumb.
lines.text: For one to thrust his Hand betweene his Teeth,

lines.speaker: Northumb.
lines.text: When he might spurne him with his Foot away?

lines.speaker: Northumb.
lines.text: It is Warres prize, to take all Vantages,

lines.speaker: Northumb.
lines.text: And tenne to one, is no impeach of Valour.

lines.speaker: Clifford.
lines.text: I, I, so striues the Woodcocke with the

lines.speaker: Northumb.
lines.text: So doth the Connie struggle in the

lines.speaker: York.
lines.text: So triumph Theeues vpon their conquer'd Booty,

lines.speaker: York.
lines.text: So True men yeeld with Robbers, so o're‑matcht.

lines.speaker: Northumb.
lines.text: What would your Grace haue done vnto

lines.speaker: Queene.
lines.text: Braue Warriors, {% italic: Clifford %}, and {% italic: Northumberland %},

lines.speaker: Queene.
lines.text: Come make him stand vpon this Mole‑hill here,

lines.speaker: Queene.
lines.text: That raught at Mountaines with out‑stretched Armes,

lines.speaker: Queene.
lines.text: Yet parted but the shadow with his Hand.

lines.speaker: Queene.
lines.text: What, was it you that would be Englands King?

lines.speaker: Queene.
lines.text: Was't you that reuell'd in our Parliament,

lines.speaker: Queene.
lines.text: And made a Preachment of you high Descent?

lines.speaker: Queene.
lines.text: Where are your Messe of Sonnes, to back you now? This question mark type has slipped below the line.

lines.speaker: Queene.
lines.text: The wanton {% italic: Edward %}, and the lustie {% italic: George? %}

lines.speaker: Queene.
lines.text: And where's that valiant Crook‑back Prodigie,

lines.speaker: Queene.
lines.text: {% italic: Dickie %}, your Boy, that with his grumbling voyce

lines.text: Or with the rest, where is your Darling, {% italic: Rutland? %}

lines.speaker: Queene.

lines.speaker: Queene.
lines.text: That valiant {% italic: Clifford %}, with his Rapiers point,

lines.speaker: Queene.
lines.text: And if thine eyes can water for his death,

lines.speaker: Queene.
lines.text: I giue thee this to drie thy Cheekes withall.

lines.speaker: Queene.
lines.text: Alas poore {% italic: Yorke %}, but that I hate thee deadly,

lines.speaker: Queene.
lines.text: I should lament thy miserable state.

lines.speaker: Queene.
lines.text: I prythee grieue, to make me merry, {% italic: Yorke %}.

lines.speaker: Queene.
lines.text: What, hath thy fierie heart so parcht thine entrayles,

lines.speaker: Queene.
lines.text: That not a Teare can fall, for {% italic: Rutlands %} death?

lines.speaker: Queene.
lines.text: Why art thou patient, man? thou should'st be mad:

lines.speaker: Queene.
lines.text: And I, to make thee mad, doe mock thee thus.

lines.speaker: Queene.
lines.text: Stampe, raue, and fret, that I may sing and dance.

lines.speaker: Queene.
lines.text: Thou would'st be fee'd, I see, to make me sport:

lines.speaker: Queene.
lines.text: {% italic: Yorke %} cannot speake, vnlesse he weare a Crowne.

lines.speaker: Queene.
lines.text: A Crowne for {% italic: Yorke %}; and Lords, bow lowe to him:

lines.speaker: Queene.
lines.text: Hold you his hands, whilest I doe set it on.

lines.speaker: Queene.
lines.text: I marry Sir, now lookes he like a King:

lines.speaker: Queene.
lines.text: I, this is he that tooke King {% italic: Henries %} Chaire,

lines.speaker: Queene.
lines.text: And this is he was his adopted Heire.

lines.speaker: Queene.
lines.text: But how is it, that great {% italic: Plantagenet %}

lines.speaker: Queene.
lines.text: Is crown'd so soone, and broke his solemne Oath?

lines.speaker: Queene.
lines.text: As I bethinke me, you should not be King,

lines.speaker: Queene.
lines.text: Till our King {% italic: Henry %} had shooke hands with Death.

lines.speaker: Queene.
lines.text: And will you pale your head in {% italic: Henries %} Glory,

lines.speaker: Queene.
lines.text: And rob his Temples of the Diademe,

lines.speaker: Queene.
lines.text: Now in his Life, against your holy Oath?

lines.speaker: Queene.
lines.text: Oh 'tis a fault too too vnpardonable.

lines.speaker: Queene.

lines.speaker: Queene.
lines.text: And whilest we breathe, take time to doe him dead.

lines.speaker: Clifford.

lines.text: Nay stay, let's heare the Orizons hee

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: Shee‑Wolfe of France,

lines.speaker: Yorke.

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: Whose Tongue more poysons then the Adders Tooth:

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: How ill‑beseeming is it in thy Sex,

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: To triumph like an Amazonian Trull,

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: Vpon their Woes, whom Fortune captiuates?

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: But that thy Face is Vizard‑like, vnchanging,

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: Made impudent with vse of euill deedes.

lines.text: I would assay, prowd Queene, to make thee blush.

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: To tell thee whence thou cam'st, of whom deriu'd,

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: Were shame enough, to shame thee,

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: Wert thou not shamelesse.

lines.speaker: Yorke.

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: Of both the Sicils, and Ierusalem,

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: Yet not so wealthie as an English Yeoman.

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: Hath that poore Monarch taught thee to insult?

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: Vnlesse the Adage must be verify'd,

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: That Beggers mounted, runne their Horse to death.

lines.text: 'Tis Beautie that doth oft make Women prowd,

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: But God he knowes, thy share thereof is small.

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: 'Tis Vertue, that doth make them most admir'd,

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: The contrary, doth make thee wondred at.

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: 'Tis Gouernment that makes them seeme Diuine,

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: The want thereof, makes thee abhominable.

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: Thou art as opposite to euery good,

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: As the {% italic: Antipodes %} are vnto vs,

lines.speaker: Yorke.
