lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: Oh Tygres Heart, wrapt in a Womans Hide,

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: How could'st thou drayne the Life‑blood of the Child,

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: To bid the Father wipe his eyes withall,

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: And yet be seene to beare a Womans face?

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: Women are soft, milde, pittifull, and flexible;

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: Thou, sterne, obdurate, flintie, rough, remorselesse.

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: Bidst thou me rage? why now thou hast thy wish.

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: Would'st haue me weepe? why now thou hast thy will.

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: For raging Wind blowes vp incessant showers,

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: And when the Rage allayes, the Raine begins.

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: These Teares are my sweet {% italic: Rutlands %} Obsequies,

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: And euery drop cryes vengeance for his death,

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: 'Gainst thee fell {% italic: Clifford %}, and thee false French‑woman.

lines.speaker: Northumb.
lines.text: Beshrew me, but his passions moues me so,

lines.speaker: Northumb.
lines.text: That hardly can I check my eyes from Teares.

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: That Face of his,

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: The hungry Caniballs would not haue toucht,

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: Would not haue stayn'd with blood:

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: But you are more inhumane, more inexorable,

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: Oh, tenne times more then Tygers of Hyrcania.

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: See, ruthlesse Queene, a haplesse Fathers Teares:

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: This Cloth thou dipd'st in blood of my sweet Boy,

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: And I with Teares doe wash the blood away.

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: Keepe thou the Napkin, and goe boast of this,

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: And if thou tell'st the heauie storie right,

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: Vpon my Soule, the hearers will shed Teares:

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: Yea, euen my Foes will shed fast‑falling Teares,

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: And say, Alas, it was a pittious deed.

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: There, take the Crowne, and with the Crowne, my Curse,

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: And in thy need, such comfort come to thee,

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: As now I reape at thy too cruell hand.

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: Hard‑hearted {% italic: Clifford %}, take me from the World,

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: My Soule to Heauen, my Blood vpon your Heads.

lines.speaker: Northumb.
lines.text: Had he been slaughter‑man to all my Kinne,

lines.speaker: Northumb.
lines.text: I should not for my Life but weepe with him,

lines.speaker: Northumb.
lines.text: To see how inly Sorrow gripes his Soule.

lines.speaker: Queene.
lines.text: What, weeping ripe, my Lord {% italic: Northumberland? %}

lines.speaker: Queene.
lines.text: Thinke but vpon the wrong he did vs all,

lines.speaker: Queene.
lines.text: And that will quickly drie thy melting Teares.

lines.speaker: Clifford.
lines.text: Heere's for my Oath, heere's for my Fathers

lines.speaker: Queene.
lines.text: And heere's to right our gentle‑hearted

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: Open thy Gate of Mercy, gracious God,

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: My Soule flyes through these wounds, to seeke out thee.

lines.speaker: Queene.
lines.text: Off with his Head, and set it on Yorke Gates,

lines.speaker: Queene.
lines.text: So {% italic: Yorke %} may ouer‑looke the Towne of Yorke.

lines.speaker: Edward.
lines.text: I wonder how our Princely Father scap't:

lines.speaker: Edward.
lines.text: Or whether he be scap't away, or no,

lines.speaker: Edward.
lines.text: From {% italic: Cliffords %} and {% italic: Northumberlands %} pursuit?

lines.speaker: Edward.
lines.text: Had he been ta'ne, we should haue heard the newes;

lines.speaker: Edward.
lines.text: Had he beene slaine, we should haue heard the newes:

lines.speaker: Edward.
lines.text: Or had he scap't, me thinkes we should haue heard

lines.speaker: Edward.
lines.text: The happy tidings of his good escape.

lines.speaker: Edward.
lines.text: How fares my Brother? why is he so sad?

lines.speaker: Richard.
lines.text: I cannot ioy, vntill I be resolu'd

lines.speaker: Richard.
lines.text: Where our right valiant Father is become.

lines.speaker: Richard.
lines.text: I saw him in the Battaile range about,

lines.speaker: Richard.
lines.text: And watcht him how he fingled {% italic: Clifford %} forth.

lines.speaker: Richard.
lines.text: Me thought he bore him in the thickest troupe,

lines.speaker: Richard.
lines.text: As doth a Lyon in a Heard of Neat,

lines.speaker: Richard.
lines.text: Or as a Beare encompass'd round with Dogges:

lines.speaker: Richard.
lines.text: Who hauing pincht a few, and made them cry,

lines.speaker: Richard.
lines.text: The rest stand all aloofe, and barke at him.

lines.speaker: Richard.
lines.text: So far'd our Father with his Enemies,

lines.speaker: Richard.
lines.text: So fled his Enemies my Warlike Father:

lines.speaker: Richard.
lines.text: Me thinkes 'tis prize enough to be his Sonne.

lines.speaker: Richard.
lines.text: See how the Morning opes her golden Gates,

lines.speaker: Richard.
lines.text: And takes her farwell of the glorious Sunne.

lines.speaker: Richard.
lines.text: How well resembles it the prime of Youth,

lines.speaker: Richard.
lines.text: Trimm'd like a Yonker, prauncing to his Loue?

lines.speaker: Ed.
lines.text: Dazle mine eyes, or doe I see three Sunnes?

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Three glorious Sunnes, each one a perfect Sunne,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Not seperated with the racking Clouds,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: But seuer'd in a pale cleare‑shining Skye.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: See, see, they ioyne, embrace, and seeme to kisse,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: As if they vow'd some League inuiolable.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Now are they but one Lampe, one Light, one Sunne:

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: In this, the Heauen figures some euent.

lines.speaker: Edward.
lines.text: 'Tis wondrous strange,

lines.speaker: Edward.
lines.text: The like yet neuer heard of.

lines.speaker: Edward.
lines.text: I thinke it cites vs (Brother) to the field,

lines.speaker: Edward.
lines.text: That wee, the Sonnes of braue {% italic: Plantagenet %},

lines.speaker: Edward.
lines.text: Each one alreadie blazing by our meedes,

lines.speaker: Edward.
lines.text: Should notwithstanding ioyne our Lights together,

lines.speaker: Edward.
lines.text: And ouer‑shine the Earth, as this the World.

lines.speaker: Edward.
lines.text: What ere it bodes, hence‑forward will I beare

lines.speaker: Edward.
lines.text: Vpon my Targuet three faire shining Sunnes.

lines.speaker: Richard.
lines.text: Nay, beare three Daughters:

lines.speaker: Richard.
lines.text: By your leaue, I speake it,

lines.speaker: Richard.
lines.text: You loue the Breeder better then the Male.

lines.speaker: Richard.
lines.text: But what art thou, whose heauie Lookes fore‑tell

lines.speaker: Richard.
lines.text: Some dreadfull story hanging on thy Tongue?

lines.speaker: Mess.
lines.text: Ah, one that was a wofull looker on,

lines.speaker: Mess.
lines.text: When as the Noble Duke of Yorke was slaine,

lines.speaker: Mess.
lines.text: Your Princely Father, and my louing Lord.

lines.speaker: Edward.
lines.text: Oh speake no more, for I haue heard too

lines.speaker: Richard.
lines.text: Say how he dy'de, for I will heare it all.

lines.speaker: Mess.
lines.text: Enuironed he was with many foes,

lines.speaker: Mess.
lines.text: And stood against them, as the hope of Troy

lines.speaker: Mess.
lines.text: Against the Greekes, that would haue entred Troy.

lines.speaker: Mess.
lines.text: But {% italic: Hercules %} himselfe must yeeld to oddes:

lines.speaker: Mess.
lines.text: And many stroakes, though with a little Axe,

lines.speaker: Mess.
lines.text: Hewes downe and fells the hardest‑tymber'd Oake.

lines.speaker: Mess.
lines.text: By many hands your Father was subdu'd,

lines.speaker: Mess.
lines.text: But onely slaught'red by the irefull Arme

lines.speaker: Mess.
lines.text: Of vn‑relenting {% italic: Clifford %}, and the Queene:

lines.speaker: Mess.
lines.text: Who crown'd the gracious Duke in high despight,

lines.speaker: Mess.
lines.text: Laugh'd in his face: and when with griefe he wept,

lines.speaker: Mess.
lines.text: The ruthlesse Queene gaue him, to dry his Cheekes,

lines.speaker: Mess.
lines.text: A Napkin, steeped in the harmelesse blood

lines.speaker: Mess.
lines.text: Of sweet young {% italic: Rutland %}, by rough {% italic: Clifford %} slaine:

lines.speaker: Mess.
lines.text: And after many scornes, many foule taunts,

lines.speaker: Mess.
lines.text: They tooke his Head, and on the Gates of Yorke

lines.speaker: Mess.
lines.text: They set the same, and there it doth remaine,

lines.speaker: Mess.
lines.text: The saddest spectacle that ere I view'd.

lines.speaker: Edward.
lines.text: Sweet Duke of Yorke, our Prop to leane vpon,

lines.speaker: Edward.
lines.text: Now thou art gone, wee haue no Staffe, no Stay.

lines.speaker: Edward.
lines.text: Oh {% italic: Clifford %}, boyst'rous {% italic: Clifford %}, thou hast slaine

lines.speaker: Edward.
lines.text: The flowre of Europe, for his Cheualrie,

lines.speaker: Edward.
lines.text: And trecherously hast thou vanquisht him,

lines.speaker: Edward.
lines.text: For hand to hand he would haue vanquisht thee.

lines.speaker: Edward.
lines.text: Now my Soules Pallace is become a Prison:

lines.speaker: Edward.
lines.text: Ah, would she breake from hence, that this my body

lines.speaker: Edward.
lines.text: Might in the ground be closed vp in rest:

lines.speaker: Edward.
lines.text: For neuer henceforth shall I ioy againe:

lines.speaker: Edward.
lines.text: Neuer, oh neuer shall I see more ioy.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: I cannot weepe: for all my bodies moysture

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Scarse serues to quench my Furnace‑burning hart:

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Nor can my tongue vnloade my hearts great burthen,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: For selfe‑same winde that I would speake withall,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Is kindling coales that fires all my brest,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: And burnes me vp with flames, that tears would quench,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: To weepe, is to make lesse the depth of greefe:

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Teares then for Babes; Blowes, and Reuenge for mee.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: {% italic: Richard %}, I beare thy name, Ile venge thy death,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Or dye renowned by attempting it.

lines.speaker: Ed.
lines.text: His name that valiant Duke hath left with thee:

lines.speaker: Ed.
lines.text: His Dukedome, and his Chaire with me is left.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Nay, if thou be that Princely Eagles Bird,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Shew thy descent by gazing 'gainst the Sunne:

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: For Chaire and Dukedome, Throne and Kingdome say,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Either that is thine, or else thou wer't not his.

lines.speaker: Warwick.
lines.text: How now faire Lords? What faire? What

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Great Lord of Warwicke, if we should recompt

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Our balefull newes, and at each words deliuerance

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Stab Poniards in our flesh, till all were told,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: The words would adde more anguish then the wounds.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: O valiant Lord, the Duke of Yorke is slaine.

lines.speaker: Edw.
lines.text: O Warwicke, Warwicke, that {% italic: Plantagenet %}

lines.speaker: Edw.
lines.text: Which held thee deerely, as his Soules Redemption,

lines.speaker: Edw.
lines.text: Is by the sterne Lord {% italic: Clifford %} done to death.

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: Ten dayes ago, I drown'd these newes in teares.

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: And now to adde more measure to your woes,

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: I come to tell you things sith then befalne.

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: After the bloody Fray at Wakefield fought,

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: Where your braue Father breath'd his latest gaspe,

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: Tydings, as swiftly as the Postes could runne,

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: Were brought me of your Losse, and his Depart.

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: I then in London, keeper of the King,

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: Muster'd my Soldiers, gathered flockes of Friends,

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: Marcht toward Albons, to intercept the Queene,

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: Bearing the King in my behalfe along:

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: For by my Scouts, I was aduertised

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: That she was comming with a full intent

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: To dash our late Decree in Parliament,

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: Touching King {% italic: Henries %} Oath, and your Succession:

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: Short Tale to make, we at Albons met,

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: Our Battailes ioyn'd, and both sides fiercely fought:

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: But whether 'twas the coldnesse of the King,

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: Who look'd full gently on his warlike Queene,

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: That robb'd my Soldiers of their heated Spleene.

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: Or whether 'twas report of her successe,

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: Or more then common feare of {% italic: Cliffords %} Rigour,

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: Who thunders to his Captiues, Blood and Death,

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: I cannot iudge: but to conclude with truth,

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: Their Weapons like to Lightning, came and went:

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: Our Souldiers like the Night‑Owles lazie flight,

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: Or like a lazie Thresher with a Flaile,

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: Fell gently downe, as if they strucke their Friends.

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: I cheer'd them vp with iustice of our Cause,

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: With promise of high pay, and great Rewards:

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: But all in vaine, they had no heart to fight,

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: And we (in them) no hope to win the day,

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: So that we fled: the King vnto the Queene,

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: Lord {% italic: George %}, your Brother, Norfolke, and my Selfe,

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: In haste, post haste, are come to ioyne with you:

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: For in the Marches heere we heard you were,

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: Making another Head, to fight againe.

lines.speaker: Ed.
lines.text: Where is the Duke of Norfolke, gentle Warwick?

lines.speaker: Ed.
lines.text: And when came {% italic: George %} from Burgundy to England?

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: Some six miles off the Duke is with the Soldiers,

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: And for your Brother be was lately sent

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: From your kinde Aunt Dutchesse of Burgundie,

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: With ayde of Souldiers to this needfull Warre.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: 'Twas oddes belike, when valiant Warwick fled;

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Oft haue I heard his praises in Pursuite,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: But ne're till now, his Scandall of Retire.

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: Nor now my Scandall {% italic: Richard %}, dost thou heare:

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: For thou shalt know this strong right hand of mine,

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: Can plucke the Diadem from faint {% italic: Henries %} head,

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: And wring the awefull Scepter from his Fist,

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: Were he as famous, and as bold in Warre,

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: As he is fam'd for Mildnesse, Peace, and Prayer.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: I know it well Lord Warwick, blame me not,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: 'Tis loue I beare thy glories make me speake:

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: But in this troublous time, what's to be done ?

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Shall we go throw away our Coates of Steele,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: And wrap our bodies in blacke mourning Gownes,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Numb'ring our Aue‑Maries with our Beads?

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Or shall we on the Helmets of our Foes

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Tell our Deuotion with reuengefull Armes?

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: If for the last, say I, and to it Lords.

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: Why therefore Warwick came to seek you out,

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: And therefore comes my Brother {% italic: Mountague %}:

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: Attend me Lords, the proud insulting Queene,

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: With {% italic: Clifford %}, and the haught Northumberland,

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: And of their Feather, many moe proud Birds,

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: Haue wrought the easie‑melting King, like Wax.

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: He swore consent to your Succession,

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: His Oath enrolled in the Parliament.

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: And now to London all the crew are gone,

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: To frustrate both his Oath, and what beside

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: May make against the house of Lancaster.

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: Their power (I thinke) is thirty thousand strong:

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: Now, if the helpe of Norfolke, and my selfe,

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: With all the Friends that thou braue Earle of March,

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: Among'st the louing Welshmen can'st procure,

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: Will but amount to fiue and twenty thousand,

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: Why Via, to London will we march,

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: And once againe, bestride our foaming Steeds,

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: And once againe cry Charge vpon our Foes,

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: But neuer once againe turne backe and flye.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: I, now me thinks I heare great Warwick speak;

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Ne're may he liue to see a Sun‑shine day,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: That cries Retire, if Warwicke bid him stay.

lines.speaker: Ed.
lines.text: Lord Warwicke, on thy shoulder will I leane,

lines.speaker: Ed.
lines.text: And when thou failst (as God forbid the houre)

lines.speaker: Ed.
lines.text: Must {% italic: Edward %} fall, which perill heauen forefend.

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: No longer Earle of March, but Duke of Yorke:

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: The next degree, is Englands Royall Throne:

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: For King of England shalt thou be proclaim'd

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: In euery Burrough as we passe along,

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: And he that throwes not vp his cap for ioy,

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: Shall for the Fault make forfeit of his head.

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: King {% italic: Edward %}, valiant {% italic: Richard Mountague %}:

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: Stay we no longer, dreaming of Renowne,

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: But sound the Trumpets, and about our Taske.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Then {% italic: Clifford %}, were thy heart as hard as Steele,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: As thou hast shewne it flintie by thy deeds,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: I come to pierce it, or to giue thee mine.

lines.speaker: Ed.
lines.text: Then strike vp Drums, God and George for vs.

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: How now? what newes?

lines.speaker: Mes.
lines.text: The Duke of Norfolke sends you word by me,

lines.speaker: Mes.
lines.text: The Queene is comming with a puissant Hoast,

lines.speaker: Mes.
lines.text: And craues your company, for speedy counsell.

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: Why then it sorts, braue Warriors, let's away.

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Welcome my Lord, to this braue town of Yorke,

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Yonders the head of that Arch‑enemy,

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: That sought to be incompast with your Crowne.

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Doth not the obiect cheere your heart, my Lord.

lines.speaker: K.
lines.text: I, as the rockes cheare them that feare their wrack,

lines.speaker: K.
lines.text: To see this sight, it irkes my very soule:

lines.speaker: K.
lines.text: With‑hold reuenge (deere God) 'tis not my fault,

lines.speaker: K.
lines.text: Nor wittingly haue I infring'd my Vow.

lines.speaker: Clif.
lines.text: My gracious Liege, this too much lenity

lines.speaker: Clif.
lines.text: And harmfull pitty must be layd aside:

lines.speaker: Clif.
lines.text: To whom do Lyons cast their gentle Lookes ?

lines.speaker: Clif.
lines.text: Not to the Beast, that would vsurpe their Den.

lines.speaker: Clif.
lines.text: Whose hand is that the Forrest Beare doth licke?

lines.speaker: Clif.
lines.text: Not his that spoyles her yong before her face.

lines.speaker: Clif.
lines.text: Who scapes the lurking Serpents mortall sting?

lines.speaker: Clif.
lines.text: Not he that sets his foot vpon her backe.

lines.speaker: Clif.
lines.text: The smallest Worme will turne, being troden on,

lines.speaker: Clif.
lines.text: And Doues will pecke in safegard of their Brood.

lines.speaker: Clif.
lines.text: Ambitious Yorke, did leuell at thy Crowne,

lines.speaker: Clif.
lines.text: Thou smiling, while he knit his angry browes.

lines.speaker: Clif.
lines.text: He but a Duke, would haue his Sonne a King,

lines.speaker: Clif.
lines.text: And raise his issue like a louing Sire.

lines.speaker: Clif.
lines.text: Thou being a King, blest with a goodly sonne,

lines.speaker: Clif.
lines.text: Did'st yeeld consent to disinherit him:

lines.speaker: Clif.
lines.text: Which argued thee a most vnlouing Father.

lines.speaker: Clif.
lines.text: Vnreasonable Creatures feed their young,

lines.speaker: Clif.
lines.text: And though mans face be fearefull to their eyes,

lines.speaker: Clif.
lines.text: Yet in protection of their tender ones,

lines.speaker: Clif.
lines.text: Who hath not seene them euen with those wings,

lines.speaker: Clif.
lines.text: Which sometime they haue vs'd with fearfull flight,

lines.speaker: Clif.
lines.text: Make warre with him that climb'd vnto their nest,

lines.speaker: Clif.
lines.text: Offering their owne liues in their yongs defence?

lines.speaker: Clif.
lines.text: For shame, my Liege, make them your President:

lines.speaker: Clif.
lines.text: Were it not pitty that this goodly Boy

lines.speaker: Clif.
lines.text: Should loose his Birth‑right by his Fathers fault,

lines.speaker: Clif.
lines.text: And long heereafter say vnto his childe,

lines.speaker: Clif.
lines.text: What my great Grandfather, and Grandsire got,

lines.speaker: Clif.
lines.text: My carelesse Father fondly gaue away.

lines.speaker: Clif.
lines.text: Ah, what a shame were this? Looke on the Boy,

lines.speaker: Clif.
lines.text: And let his manly face, which promiseth

lines.speaker: Clif.
lines.text: Successefull Fortune steele thy melting heart,

lines.speaker: Clif.
lines.text: To hold thine owne, and leaue thine owne with him.

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: Full well hath {% italic: Clifford %} plaid the Orator,

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: Inferring arguments of mighty force:

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: But {% italic: Clifford %} tell me, did'st thou neuer heare,

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: That things ill got, had euer bad successe.

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: And happy alwayes was it for that Sonne,

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: Whose Father for his hoording went to hell:

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: Ile leaue my Sonne my Vertuous deeds behinde,

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: And would my Father had left me no more:

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: For all the rest is held at such a Rate,

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: As brings a thousand fold more care to keepe,

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: Then in possession any iot of pleasure.

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: Ah Cosin Yorke, would thy best Friends did know,

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: How it doth greeue me that thy head is heere.

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: My Lord cheere vp your spirits, our foes are nye,

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: And this soft courage makes your Followers faint:

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: You promist Knighthood to our forward sonne,

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Vnsheath your sword, and dub him presently.

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: {% italic: Edward %}, kneele downe.

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: {% italic: Edward Plantagenet %}, arise a Knight,

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: And learne this Lesson; Draw thy Sword in right.

lines.speaker: Prin.
lines.text: My gracious Father, by your Kingly leaue,

lines.speaker: Prin.
lines.text: Ile draw it as Apparant to the Crowne,

lines.speaker: Prin.
lines.text: And in that quarrell, vse it to the death.

lines.speaker: Clif.
lines.text: Why that is spoken like a toward Prince.

lines.speaker: Mess.
lines.text: Royall Commanders, be in readinesse,

lines.speaker: Mess.
lines.text: For with a Band of thirty thousand men,

lines.speaker: Mess.
lines.text: Comes Warwicke backing of the Duke of Yorke,

lines.speaker: Mess.
lines.text: And in the Townes as they do march along,

lines.speaker: Mess.
lines.text: Proclaimes him King, and many flye to him,

lines.speaker: Mess.
lines.text: Darraigne your battell, for they are at hand.

lines.speaker: Clif.
lines.text: I would your Highnesse would depart the field,

lines.speaker: Clif.
lines.text: The Queene hath best successe when you are absent.

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: I good my Lord, and leaue vs to our Fortune.

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: Why, that's my fortune too, therefore Ile stay.

lines.speaker: North.
lines.text: Be it with resolution then to fight.

lines.speaker: Prin.
lines.text: My Royall Father, cheere these Noble Lords,

lines.speaker: Prin.
lines.text: And hearten those that fight in your defence:

lines.speaker: Prin.
lines.text: Vnsheath your Sword, good Father: Cry George.

lines.speaker: Edw.
lines.text: Now periur'd {% italic: Henry %}, wilt thou kneel for grace?

lines.speaker: Edw.
lines.text: And set thy Diadem vpon my head?

lines.speaker: Edw.
lines.text: Or bide the mortall Fortune of the field.

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Go rate thy Minions, proud insulting Boy,

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Becomes it thee to be thus bold in termes,

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Before thy Soueraigne, and thy lawfull King?

lines.speaker: Ed.
lines.text: I am his King, and he should bow his knee:

lines.speaker: Ed.
lines.text: I was adopted Heire by his consent.

lines.speaker: Cla.
lines.text: Since when, his Oath is broke: for as I heare,

lines.speaker: Cla.
lines.text: You that are King, though he do weare the Crowne,

lines.speaker: Cla.
lines.text: Haue caus'd him by new Act of Parliament,

lines.speaker: Cla.
lines.text: To blot out me, and put his owne Sonne in.

lines.speaker: Clif.
lines.text: And reason too,

lines.speaker: Clif.
lines.text: Who should succeede the Father, but the Sonne.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Are you there Butcher? O, I cannot speake.

lines.speaker: Clif.
lines.text: I Crooke‑back, here I stand to answer thee,

lines.speaker: Clif.
lines.text: Or any he, the proudest of thy sort.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: 'Twas you that kill'd yong Rutland, was it not?

lines.speaker: Clif.
lines.text: I, and old Yorke, and yet not satisfied.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: For Gods sake Lords giue signall to the fight.

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: What say'st thou {% italic: Henry %},

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: Wilt thou yeeld the Crowne?

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Why how now long‑tongu'd Warwicke, dare ( you speak?

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: When you and I, met at {% italic: Albons %} last,

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Your legges did better seruice then your hands.

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: Then 'twas my turne to fly, and now 'tis thine:

lines.speaker: Clif.
lines.text: You said so much before, and yet you fled.

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: 'Twas not your valor {% italic: Clifford %} droue me thence.

lines.speaker: Nor.
lines.text: No, nor your manhood that durst make you stay.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Northumberland, I hold thee reuerently,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Breake off the parley, for scarse I can refraine

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: The execution of my big‑swolne heart

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Vpon that {% italic: Clifford %}, that cruell Child‑killer.

lines.speaker: Clif.
lines.text: I slew thy Father, cal'st thou him a Child?

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: I like a Dastard, and a treacherous Coward,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: As thou didd'st kill our tender Brother Rutland,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: But ere Sunset, Ile make thee curse the deed.

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: Haue done with words (my Lords) and heare

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Defie them then, or els hold close thy lips.

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: I prythee giue no limits to my Tongue,

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: I am a King, and priuiledg'd to speake.

lines.speaker: Clif.
lines.text: My Liege, the Wound that bred this meeting here,

lines.speaker: Clif.
lines.text: Cannot be cur'd by Words, therefore be still.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Then Executioner vnsheath thy sword:

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: By him that made vs all, I am resolu'd,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: That {% italic: Cliffords %} Manhood, lyes vpon his tongue.

lines.speaker: Ed.
lines.text: Say {% italic: Henry %}, shall I haue my right, or no:

lines.speaker: Ed.
lines.text: A thousand men haue broke their Fasts to day,

lines.speaker: Ed.
lines.text: That ne're shall dine, vnlesse thou yeeld the Crowne.

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: If thou deny, their Blood vpon thy head,

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: For Yorke in iustice put's his Armour on.

lines.speaker: Pr. Ed.
lines.text: If that be right, which Warwick saies is right,

lines.speaker: Pr. Ed.
lines.text: There is no vvrong, but euery thing is right.

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: Who euer got thee, there thy Mother stands,

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: For well I vvot, thou hast thy Mothers tongue.

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: But thou art neyther like thy Sire nor Damme,

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: But like a foule mishapen Stygmaticke,

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Mark'd by the Destinies to be auoided,

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: As venome Toades, or Lizards dreadfull stings.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Iron of Naples, hid with English gilt,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Whose Father beares the Title of a King,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: (As if a Channell should be call'd the Sea)

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Sham'st thou not, knowing whence thou art extraught,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: To let thy tongue detect thy base‑borne heart.

lines.speaker: Ed.
lines.text: A wispe of straw were worth a thousand Crowns,

lines.speaker: Ed.
lines.text: To make this shamelesse Callet know her selfe:

lines.speaker: Ed.
lines.text: {% italic: Helen %} of Greece was fayrer farre then thou,

lines.speaker: Ed.
lines.text: Although thy Husband may be {% italic: Menelaus %};

lines.speaker: Ed.
lines.text: And ne're was {% italic: Agamemnons %} Brother wrong'd

lines.speaker: Ed.
lines.text: By that false Woman, as this King by thee.

lines.speaker: Ed.
lines.text: His Father reuel'd in the heart of France,

lines.speaker: Ed.
lines.text: And tam'd the King, and made the Dolphin stoope:

lines.speaker: Ed.
lines.text: And had he match'd according to his State,

lines.speaker: Ed.
lines.text: He might haue kept that glory to this day.

lines.speaker: Ed.
lines.text: But when he tooke a begger to his bed,

lines.speaker: Ed.
lines.text: And grac'd thy poore Sire with his Bridall day,

lines.speaker: Ed.
lines.text: Euen then that Sun‑shine brew'd a showre for him,

lines.speaker: Ed.
lines.text: That washt his Fathers fortunes forth of France,

lines.speaker: Ed.
lines.text: And heap'd sedition on his Crowne at home:

lines.speaker: Ed.
lines.text: For what hath broach'd this tumult but thy Pride?

lines.speaker: Ed.
lines.text: Had'st thou bene meeke, our Title still had slept,

lines.speaker: Ed.
lines.text: And we in pitty of the Gentle King,

lines.speaker: Ed.
lines.text: Had slipt our Claime, vntill another Age.

lines.speaker: Cla.
lines.text: But when we saw, our Sunshine made thy Spring,

lines.speaker: Cla.
lines.text: And that thy Summer bred vs no increase,

lines.speaker: Cla.
lines.text: We set the Axe to thy vsurping Roote:

lines.speaker: Cla.
lines.text: And though the edge hath something hit our selues,

lines.speaker: Cla.
lines.text: Yet know thou, since we haue begun to strike,

lines.speaker: Cla.
lines.text: Wee'l neuer leaue, till we haue hewne thee downe,

lines.speaker: Cla.
lines.text: Or bath'd thy growing, with our heated bloods.

lines.speaker: Edw.
lines.text: And in this resolution, I defie thee,

lines.speaker: Edw.
lines.text: Not willing any longer Conference,

lines.speaker: Edw.
lines.text: Since thou denied'st the gentle King to speake.

lines.speaker: Edw.
lines.text: Sound Trumpets, let our bloody Colours waue,

lines.speaker: Edw.
lines.text: And either Victorie, or else a Graue.

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Stay {% italic: Edward %}.

lines.speaker: Ed.
lines.text: No wrangling Woman, wee'l no longer stay,

lines.speaker: Ed.
lines.text: These words will cost ten thousand liues this day.

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: Fore‑spent with Toile, as Runners with a Race,

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: I lay me downe a little while to breath:

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: For strokes receiu'd, and many blowes repaid,

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: Haue robb'd my strong knit sinewes of their strength,

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: And spight of spight, needs must I rest a‑while.

lines.speaker: Ed.
lines.text: Smile gentle heauen, or strike vngentle death,

lines.speaker: Ed.
lines.text: For this world frownes, and {% italic: Edwards %} Sunne is clowded.

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: How now my Lord, what happe? what hope of

lines.speaker: Cla.
lines.text: Our hap is losse, our hope but sad dispaire,

lines.speaker: Cla.
lines.text: Our rankes are broke, and ruine followes vs.

lines.speaker: Cla.
lines.text: What counsaile giue you? whether shall we flye?

lines.speaker: Ed.
lines.text: Bootlesse is flight, they follow vs with Wings,

lines.speaker: Ed.
lines.text: And weake we are, and cannot shun pursuite.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Ah Warwicke, why hast y u withdrawn thy selfe?

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Thy Brothers blood the thirsty earth hath drunk,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Broach'd with the Steely point of {% italic: Cliffords %} Launce:

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: And in the very pangs of death, he cryde,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Like to a dismall Clangor heard from farre,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Warwicke, reuenge; Brother, reuenge my death.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: So vnderneath the belly of their Steeds,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: That stain'd their Fetlockes in his smoaking blood,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: The Noble Gentleman gaue vp the ghost.

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: Then let the earth be drunken with our blood:

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: Ile kill my Horse, because I will not flye:

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: Why stand we like soft‑hearted women heere,

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: Wayling our losses, whiles the Foe doth Rage,

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: And looke vpon, as if the Tragedie

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: Were plaid in iest, by counterfetting Actors.

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: Heere on my knee, I vow to God aboue,

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: Ile neuer pawse againe, neuer stand still,

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: Till either death hath clos'd these eyes of mine,

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: Or Fortune giuen me measure of Reuenge.

lines.speaker: Ed.
lines.text: Oh Warwicke, I do bend my knee with thine,

lines.speaker: Ed.
lines.text: And in this vow do chaine my soule to thine:

lines.speaker: Ed.
lines.text: I And ere my knee rise from the Earths cold face,

lines.speaker: Ed.
lines.text: I throw my hands, mine eyes, my heart to thee,

lines.speaker: Ed.
lines.text: Thou setter vp, and plucker downe of Kings:

lines.speaker: Ed.
lines.text: Beseeching thee (if with thy will it stands)

lines.speaker: Ed.
lines.text: That to my Foes this body must be prey,

lines.speaker: Ed.
lines.text: Yet that thy brazen gates of heauen may ope,

lines.speaker: Ed.
lines.text: And giue sweet passage to my sinfull soule.

lines.speaker: Ed.
lines.text: Now Lords, take leaue vntill we meete againe,

lines.speaker: Ed.
lines.text: Where ere it be, in heauen, or in earth.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Brother,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Giue me thy hand, and gentle Warwicke,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Let me imbrace thee in my weary armes;

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: I that did neuer weepe, now melt with wo,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: That Winter should cut off our Spring‑time so.

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: Away, away:

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: Once more sweet Lords farwell.

lines.speaker: Cla.
lines.text: Yet let vs altogether to our Troopes,

lines.speaker: Cla.
lines.text: And giue them leaue to flye, that will not stay:

lines.speaker: Cla.
lines.text: And call them Pillars that will stand to vs:

lines.speaker: Cla.
lines.text: And if we thriue, promise them such rewards

lines.speaker: Cla.
lines.text: As Victors weare at the Olympian Games.

lines.speaker: Cla.
lines.text: This may plant courage in their quailing breasts,

lines.speaker: Cla.
lines.text: For yet is hope of Life and Victory:

lines.speaker: Cla.
lines.text: Foreslow no longer, make we hence amaine.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Now {% italic: Clifford %}, I haue singled thee alone,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Suppose this arme is for the Duke of Yorke,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: And this for Rutland, both bound to reuenge,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Wer't thou inuironed with a Brazen wall.

lines.speaker: Clif,
lines.text: Now {% italic: Richard %}, I am with thee heere alone,

lines.speaker: Clif,
lines.text: This is the hand that stabb'd thy Father Yorke,

lines.speaker: Clif,
lines.text: And this the hand, that slew thy Brother Rutland,

lines.speaker: Clif,
lines.text: And here's the heart, that triumphs in their death,

lines.speaker: Clif,
lines.text: And cheeres these hands, that slew thy Sire and Brother,

lines.speaker: Clif,
lines.text: To execute the like vpon thy selfe,

lines.speaker: Clif,
lines.text: And so haue at thee.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Nay Warwicke, single out some other Chace,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: For I my selfe will hunt this Wolfe to death.

lines.speaker: Hen.
lines.text: This battell fares like to the mornings Warre,

lines.speaker: Hen.
lines.text: When dying clouds contend, with growing light,

lines.speaker: Hen.
lines.text: What time the Shepheard blowing of his nailes,

lines.speaker: Hen.
lines.text: Can neither call it perfect day, nor night.

lines.speaker: Hen.
lines.text: Now swayes it this way, like a Mighty Sea,

lines.speaker: Hen.
lines.text: Forc'd by the Tide, to combat with the Winde:

lines.speaker: Hen.
lines.text: Now swayes it that way, like the selfe‑same Sea,

lines.speaker: Hen.
lines.text: Forc'd to retyre by furie of the Winde.

lines.speaker: Hen.
lines.text: Sometime, the Flood preuailes; and than the Winde:

lines.speaker: Hen.
lines.text: Now, one the better: then, another best;

lines.speaker: Hen.
lines.text: Both tugging to be Victors, brest to brest:

lines.speaker: Hen.
lines.text: Yet neither Conqueror, nor Conquered.

lines.speaker: Hen.
lines.text: So is the equall poise of this fell Warre.

lines.speaker: Hen.
lines.text: Heere on this Mole‑hill will I sit me downe,

lines.speaker: Hen.
lines.text: To whom God will, there be the Victorie:

lines.speaker: Hen.
lines.text: For {% italic: Margaret %} my Queene, and {% italic: Clifford %} too

lines.speaker: Hen.
lines.text: Haue chid me from the Battell: Swearing both,

lines.speaker: Hen.
lines.text: They prosper best of all when I am thence.

lines.speaker: Hen.
lines.text: Would I were dead, if Gods good will were so;

lines.speaker: Hen.
lines.text: For what is in this world, but Greefe and Woe.

lines.speaker: Hen.
lines.text: Oh God! me thinkes it were a happy life,

lines.speaker: Hen.
lines.text: To be no better then a homely Swaine,

lines.speaker: Hen.
lines.text: To sit vpon a hill, as I do now,

lines.speaker: Hen.
lines.text: To carue out Dialls queintly, point by point,

lines.speaker: Hen.
lines.text: Thereby to see the Minutes how they runne:

lines.speaker: Hen.
lines.text: How many makes the Houre full compleate,

lines.speaker: Hen.
lines.text: How many Houres brings about the Day,

lines.speaker: Hen.
lines.text: How many Dayes will finish vp the Yeare,

lines.speaker: Hen.
lines.text: How many Yeares, a Mortall man may liue.

lines.speaker: Hen.
lines.text: When this is knowne, then to diuide the Times:

lines.speaker: Hen.
lines.text: So many Houres, must I tend my Flocke;:

lines.speaker: Hen.
lines.text: So many Houres, must I take my Rest:

lines.speaker: Hen.
lines.text: So many Houres, must I Contemplate:

lines.speaker: Hen.
lines.text: So many Houres, must I Sport my selfe:

lines.speaker: Hen.
lines.text: So many Dayes, my Ewes haue bene with yong:

lines.speaker: Hen.
lines.text: So many weekes, ere the poore Fooles will Eane:

lines.speaker: Hen.
lines.text: So many yeares, ere I shall sheere the Fleece:

lines.speaker: Hen.
lines.text: So Minutes, Houres, Dayes, Monthes, and Yeares,

lines.speaker: Hen.
lines.text: Past ouer to the end they were created,

lines.speaker: Hen.
lines.text: Would bring white haires, vnto a Quiet graue.

lines.speaker: Hen.
lines.text: Ah! what a life were this? How sweet? how louely?

lines.speaker: Hen.
lines.text: Giues not the Hawthorne bush a sweeter shade

lines.speaker: Hen.
lines.text: To Shepheards, looking on their silly Sheepe,

lines.speaker: Hen.
lines.text: Then doth a rich Imbroider'd Canopie

lines.speaker: Hen.
lines.text: To Kings, that feare their Subiects treacherie?

lines.speaker: Hen.
lines.text: Oh yes, it doth; a thousand fold it doth.

lines.speaker: Hen.
lines.text: And to conclude, the Shepherds homely Curds,

lines.speaker: Hen.
lines.text: His cold thinne drinke out of his Leather Bottle,

lines.speaker: Hen.
lines.text: His wonted sleepe, vnder a fresh trees shade,

lines.speaker: Hen.
lines.text: All which secure, and sweetly he enioyes,

lines.speaker: Hen.
lines.text: Is farre beyond a Princes Delicates:

lines.speaker: Hen.
lines.text: His Viands sparkling in a Golden Cup,

lines.speaker: Hen.
lines.text: His bodie couched in a curious bed,

lines.speaker: Hen.
lines.text: When Care, Mistrust, and Treason waits on him.

lines.speaker: Son.
lines.text: Ill blowes the winde that profits no body,

lines.speaker: Son.
lines.text: This man whom hand to hand I slew in fight,

lines.speaker: Son.
lines.text: May be possessed with some store of Crownes,

lines.speaker: Son.
lines.text: And I that (haply) take them from him now,

lines.speaker: Son.
lines.text: May yet (ere night) yeeld both my Life and them

lines.speaker: Son.
lines.text: To some man else, as this dead man doth me.

lines.speaker: Son.
lines.text: Who's this? Oh God! It is my Fathers face,

lines.speaker: Son.
lines.text: Whom in this Conflict, I (vnwares) have kill'd:

lines.speaker: Son.
lines.text: Oh heauy times! begetting such Euents.

lines.speaker: Son.
lines.text: From London, by the King was I prest forth,

lines.speaker: Son.
lines.text: My Father being the Earle of Warwickes man,

lines.speaker: Son.
lines.text: Came on the part of Yorke, prest by his Master;

lines.speaker: Son.
lines.text: And I, who at his hands receiu'd my life,

lines.speaker: Son.
lines.text: Haue by my hands, of Life bereaued him.

lines.speaker: Son.
lines.text: Pardon me God, I knew not what I did:

lines.speaker: Son.
lines.text: And pardon Father, for I knew not thee.

lines.speaker: Son.
lines.text: My Teares shall wipe away these bloody markes:

lines.speaker: Son.
lines.text: And no more words, till they haue flow'd their fill.

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: O pitteous spectacle! O bloody Times!

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: Whiles Lyons Warre, and battaile for their Dennes,

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: Poore harmlesse Lambes abide their enmity.

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: Weepe wretched man: Ile ayde thee Teare for Teare,

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: And let our hearts and eyes, like Ciuill Warre,

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: Be blinde with teares, and break ore‑charged with griefe

lines.speaker: Fa.
lines.text: Thou that so stoutly hath resisted me,

lines.speaker: Fa.
lines.text: Giue me thy Gold, if thou hast any Gold:

lines.speaker: Fa.
lines.text: For I haue bought it with an hundred blowes.

lines.speaker: Fa.
lines.text: But let me see: Is this our Foe‑mans face?

lines.speaker: Fa.
lines.text: Ah, no, no, no, it is mine onely Sonne.,

lines.speaker: Fa.
lines.text: Ah Boy, if any life be left in thee,

lines.speaker: Fa.
lines.text: Throw vp thine eye: see, see, what showres arise,

lines.speaker: Fa.
lines.text: Blowne with the windie Tempest of my heart,

lines.speaker: Fa.
lines.text: Vpon thy wounds, that killes mine Eye, and Heart.

lines.speaker: Fa.
lines.text: O pitty God, this miserable Age!

lines.speaker: Fa.
lines.text: What Stragems? how fell? how Butcherly?

lines.speaker: Fa.
lines.text: Erreoneous, mutinous, and vnnaturall,

lines.speaker: Fa.
lines.text: This deadly quarrell daily doth beget {% italic: ? %}

lines.speaker: Fa.
lines.text: O Boy! thy Father gaue thee life too soone,

lines.speaker: Fa.
lines.text: And hath bereft thee of thy life too late.

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: Wo aboue wo: greefe, more common greefe

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: O that my death would stay these ruthfull deeds:

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: O pitty, pitty, gentle heauen pitty:

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: The Red Rose and the White are on his face,

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: The fatall Colours of our striuing Houses:

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: The one, his purple Blood right well resembles,

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: The other his pale Cheekes (me thinkes) presenteth:

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: Wither one Rose, and let the other flourish:

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: If you contend, a thousand liues must wither.

lines.speaker: Son.
lines.text: How will my Mother, for a Fathers death

lines.speaker: Son.
lines.text: Take on with me, and ne're be satisfi'd?

lines.speaker: Fa.
lines.text: How will my Wife, for slaughter of my Sonne,

lines.speaker: Fa.
lines.text: Shed seas of Teares, and ne're be satisfi'd?

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: How will the Country, for these woful chances,

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: Mis‑thinke the King, and not be satisfied?

lines.speaker: Son.
lines.text: Was euer sonne, so rew'd a Fathers death?

lines.speaker: Fath.
lines.text: Was euer Father so bemoan'd his Sonne?

lines.speaker: Hen.
lines.text: Was euer King so greeu'd for Subiects woe?

lines.speaker: Hen.
lines.text: Much is your sorrow; Mine, ten times so much.

lines.speaker: Son.
lines.text: Ile beare thee hence, where I may weepe my fill.

lines.speaker: Fath.
lines.text: These armes of mine shall be thy winding sheet:

lines.speaker: Fath.
lines.text: My heart (sweet Boy) shall be thy Sepulcher,

lines.speaker: Fath.
lines.text: For from my heart, thine Image ne're shall go.

lines.speaker: Fath.
lines.text: My sighing brest, shall be thy Funerall bell;

lines.speaker: Fath.
lines.text: And so obsequious will thy Father be,

lines.speaker: Fath.
lines.text: Men for the losse of thee, hauing no more,

lines.speaker: Fath.
lines.text: As {% italic: Priam %} was for all his Valiant Sonnes,

lines.speaker: Fath.
lines.text: Ile beare thee hence, and let them fight that will,

lines.speaker: Fath.
lines.text: For I haue murthered where I should not kill.

lines.speaker: Hen.
lines.text: Sad‑hearted‑men, much ouergone with Care;

lines.speaker: Hen.
lines.text: Heere sits a King, more wofull then you are.

lines.speaker: Prin.
lines.text: Fly Father, flye: for all your Friends are fled.

lines.speaker: Prin.
lines.text: And Warwicke rages like a chafed Bull:

lines.speaker: Prin.
lines.text: Away, for death doth hold vs in pursuite.

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Mount you my Lord, towards Barwicke post a­

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: {% italic: Edward %} and {% italic: Richard %} like a brace of Grey‑hounds,

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Hauing the fearfull flying Hare in sight,

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: With fiery eyes, sparkling for very wrath,

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: And bloody steele graspt in their yrefull hands

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Are at our backes, and therefore hence amaine.

lines.speaker: Exet.
lines.text: Away: for vengeance comes along with them.

lines.speaker: Exet.
lines.text: Nay, stay not to expostulate, make speed,

lines.speaker: Exet.
lines.text: Or else come after, Ile away before.

lines.speaker: Hen.
lines.text: Nay take me with thee, good sweet Exeter:

lines.speaker: Hen.
lines.text: Not that I feare to stay, but loue to go

lines.speaker: Hen.
lines.text: Whether the Queene intends. Forward, away.

lines.speaker: Clif.
lines.text: Heare burnes my Candle out; I, heere it dies,

lines.speaker: Clif.
lines.text: Which whiles it lasted, gaue King {% italic: Henry %} light.

lines.speaker: Clif.
lines.text: O Lancaster! I feare thy ouerthrow,

lines.speaker: Clif.
lines.text: More then my Bodies parting with my Soule:

lines.speaker: Clif.
lines.text: My Loue and Feare, glew'd many Friends to thee,

lines.speaker: Clif.
lines.text: And now I fall. Thy tough Commixtures melts,

lines.speaker: Clif.
lines.text: Impairing {% italic: Henry %}, strength'ning misproud Yorke;

lines.speaker: Clif.
lines.text: And whether flye the Gnats, but to the Sunne?

lines.speaker: Clif.
lines.text: And who shines now, but {% italic: Henries %} Enemies?

lines.speaker: Clif.
lines.text: O Phœbus! had'st thou neuer giuen consent,

lines.speaker: Clif.
lines.text: That {% italic: Phaeton %} should checke thy fiery Steeds,

lines.speaker: Clif.
lines.text: Thy burning Carre neuer had scorch'd the earth.

lines.speaker: Clif.
lines.text: And {% italic: Henry %}, had'st thou sway'd as Kings should do,

lines.speaker: Clif.
lines.text: Or as thy Father, and his Father did,

lines.speaker: Clif.
lines.text: Giuing no ground vnto the house of Yorke,

lines.speaker: Clif.
lines.text: They neuer then had sprung like Sommer Flyes:

lines.speaker: Clif.
lines.text: I, and ten thousand in this lucklesse Realme,

lines.speaker: Clif.
lines.text: Hed left no mourning Widdowes for our death,

lines.speaker: Clif.
lines.text: And thou this day, had'st kept thy Chaire in peace.

lines.speaker: Clif.
lines.text: For what doth cherrish Weeds, but gentle ayre?

lines.speaker: Clif.
lines.text: And what makes Robbers bold, but too much lenity ?

lines.speaker: Clif.
lines.text: Bootlesse are Plaints, and Curelesse are my Wounds:

lines.speaker: Clif.
lines.text: No way to flye, nor strength to hold out flight:

lines.speaker: Clif.
lines.text: The Foe is mercilesse, and will not pitty:

lines.speaker: Clif.
lines.text: For at their hands I haue deseru'd no pitty.

lines.speaker: Clif.
lines.text: The ayre hath got into my deadly Wounds,

lines.speaker: Clif.
lines.text: And much effule of blood, doth make me faint:

lines.speaker: Clif.
lines.text: Come {% italic: Yorke %}, and {% italic: Richard, Warwicke %}, and the rest,

lines.speaker: Clif.
lines.text: I stab'd your Fathers bosomes; Split my brest.

lines.speaker: Ed.
lines.text: Now breath we Lords, good fortune bids vs pause,

lines.speaker: Ed.
lines.text: And smooth the frownes of War, with peacefull lookes:

lines.speaker: Ed.
lines.text: Some Troopes pursue the bloody‑minded Queene,

lines.speaker: Ed.
lines.text: That led calme {% italic: Henry %}, though he were a King,

lines.speaker: Ed.
lines.text: As doth a Saile, fill'd with a fretting Gust

lines.speaker: Ed.
lines.text: Command an Argosie to stemme the Waues.

lines.speaker: Ed.
lines.text: But thinke you (Lords) that Clifford fled with them?

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: No, 'tis impossible he should escape:

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: (For though before his face I speake the words)

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: Your Brother {% italic: Richard %} markt him for the Graue,

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: And wheresoere he is, hee's surely dead.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Whose soule is that which takes hir heauy leaue?

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: A deadly grone, like life and deaths departing.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: See who it is.

lines.speaker: Ed.
lines.text: And now the Battailes ended,

lines.speaker: Ed.
lines.text: If Friend or Foe, let him be gently vsed.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Reuoke that doome of mercy, for 'tis {% italic: Clifford %},

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Who not contented that he lopp'd the Branch

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: In hewing Rutland, when his leaues put forth,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: But set his murth'ring knife vnto the Roote,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: From whence that tender spray did sweetly spring,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: I meane our Princely Father, Duke of Yorke.

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: From off the gates of Yorke, fetch down head,

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: Your Fathers head, which {% italic: Ciifford %} placed there:

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: In stead whereof, let this supply the roome,

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: Measure for measure, must be answered.

lines.speaker: Ed.
lines.text: Bring forth that fatall Schreechowle to our house,

lines.speaker: Ed.
lines.text: That nothing sung but death, to vs and ours:

lines.speaker: Ed.
lines.text: Now death shall stop his dismall threatning sound,

lines.speaker: Ed.
lines.text: And his ill‑boading tongue, no more shall speake.

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: I thinke is vnderstanding is bereft:

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: Speake {% italic: Clifford %}, dost thou know who speakes to thee?

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: Darke cloudy death ore‑shades his beames of life,

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: And he nor sees, nor heares vs, what we say.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: O would he did, and so (perhaps) he doth,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: 'Tis but his policy to counterfet,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Because he would auoid such bitter taunts

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Which in the time of death he gaue our Father.

lines.speaker: Cla
lines.text: If so thou think'st,

lines.speaker: Cla
lines.text: Vex him with eager Words.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: {% italic: Clifford %}, aske mercy, and obtaine no grace.

lines.speaker: Ed.
lines.text: {% italic: Clifford %}, repent in bootlesse penitence.

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: {% italic: Clifford %}, deuise excuses for thy faults.

lines.speaker: Cla.
lines.text: While we deuise fell Tortures for thy faults.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Thou didd'st loue Yorke, and I am son to Yorke.

lines.speaker: Edw.
lines.text: Thou pittied'st Rutland, I will pitty thee.

lines.speaker: Cla.
lines.text: Where's Captaine {% italic: Margaret %}, to fence you now?

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: They mocke thee {% italic: Clifford %},

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: Sweare as thou was't wont.

lines.speaker: Ric.
lines.text: What, not an Oath? Nay then the world go's hard

lines.speaker: Ric.
lines.text: When {% italic: Clifford %} cannot spare his Friends an oath:

lines.speaker: Ric.
lines.text: I know by that he's dead, and by my Soule,

lines.speaker: Ric.
lines.text: If this right hand would buy two houres life,

lines.speaker: Ric.
lines.text: That I (in all despight) might rayle at him,

lines.speaker: Ric.
lines.text: This hand should chop it off: & with the issuing Blood

lines.speaker: Ric.
lines.text: Stifle the Villaine, whose vnstanched thirst

lines.speaker: Ric.
lines.text: Yorke, and yong Rutland could not satisfie

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: I, but he's dead. Of with the Traitors head,

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: And reare it in the place your Fathers stands.

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: And now to London with Triumphant march,

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: There to be crowned Englands Royall King:

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: From whence, shall Warwicke cut the Sea to France,

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: And aske the Ladie {% italic: Bona %} for thy Queene:

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: So shalt thou sinow both these Lands together,

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: And hauing France thy Friend, thou shalt not dread

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: The scattred Foe, that hopes to rise againe:

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: For though they cannot greatly sting to hurt,

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: Yet looke to haue them buz to offend thine eares:

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: First, will I see the Coronation,

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: And then to Britanny Ile crosse the Sea,

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: To effect this marriage, so it please my Lord.

lines.speaker: Ed.
lines.text: Euen as thou wilt sweet Warwicke, let it bee:

lines.speaker: Ed.
lines.text: For in thy shoulder do I builde my Seate;

lines.speaker: Ed.
lines.text: And neuer will I vndertake the thing

lines.speaker: Ed.
lines.text: Wherein thy counsaile and consent is wanting:

lines.speaker: Ed.
lines.text: {% italic: Richard %}, I will create thee Duke of Gloucester,

lines.speaker: Ed.
lines.text: And {% italic: George %} of Clarence; {% italic: Warwicke %} as our Selfe,

lines.speaker: Ed.
lines.text: Shall do, and vndo as him pleaseth best.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Let me be Duke of Clarence, {% italic: George %} of Gloster,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: For Glosters Dukedome is too ominous.

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: Tut, that's a foolish obseruation:

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: {% italic: Richard %}, be Duke of Gloster: Now to London,

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: To see these Honors in possession.

lines.speaker: Sink.
lines.text: Vnder this thicke growne brake, wee'l shrowd ( our selues:

lines.speaker: Sink.
lines.text: For through this Laund anon the Deere will come,

lines.speaker: Sink.
lines.text: And in this couert will we make our Stand,

lines.speaker: Sink.
lines.text: Culling the principall of all the Deere.

lines.speaker: Hum.
lines.text: Ile stay aboue the hill, so both may shoot.

lines.speaker: Sink.
lines.text: That cannot be, the noise of thy Crosse‑bow

lines.speaker: Sink.
lines.text: Will scarre the Heard, and so my shoot is lost:

lines.speaker: Sink.
lines.text: Heere stand we both, and ayme we at the best:

lines.speaker: Sink.
lines.text: And for the time shall not seeme tedious,

lines.speaker: Sink.
lines.text: Ile tell thee what befell me on a day,

lines.speaker: Sink.
lines.text: In this selfe‑place, where now we meane to stand.

lines.speaker: Sink.
lines.text: Heere comes a man, let's stay till he be past.

lines.speaker: Hen.
lines.text: From Scotland am I stolne euen of pure loue,

lines.speaker: Hen.
lines.text: To greet mine owne Land with my wishfull sight:

lines.speaker: Hen.
lines.text: No {% italic: Harry, Harry %}, 'tis no Land of thine,

lines.speaker: Hen.
lines.text: Thy place is fill'd, thy Scepter wrung from thee,

lines.speaker: Hen.
lines.text: Thy Balme washt off, wherewith thou was Annointed:

lines.speaker: Hen.
lines.text: No bending knee will call thee {% italic: Cæsar %} now,

lines.speaker: Hen.
lines.text: No humble suters prease to speake for right:

lines.speaker: Hen.
lines.text: No, not a man comes for redresse of thee:

lines.speaker: Hen.
lines.text: For how can I helpe them, and not my selfe?

lines.speaker: Sink.
lines.text: I, heere's a Deere, whose skin's a Keepers Fee:

lines.speaker: Sink.
lines.text: This is the quondam King; Let's seize vpon him.

lines.speaker: Hen.
lines.text: Let me embrace the sower Aduersaries,

lines.speaker: Hen.
lines.text: For Wise men say, it is the wisest course.

lines.speaker: Hum.
lines.text: Why linger we? Let vs lay hands vpon him.

lines.speaker: Sink.
lines.text: Forbeare a‑while, wee'l heare a little more.

lines.speaker: Hen.
lines.text: My Queene and Son are gone to France for aid:

lines.speaker: Hen.
lines.text: And (as I heare) the great Commanding Warwicke

lines.speaker: Hen.
lines.text: I: thither gone, to craue the French Kings Sister

lines.speaker: Hen.
lines.text: To wife for {% italic: Edward %}. If this newes be true,

lines.speaker: Hen.
lines.text: Poore Queene, and Sonne, your labour is but lost:

lines.speaker: Hen.
lines.text: For Warwicke is a subtle Orator:

lines.speaker: Hen.
lines.text: And {% italic: Lewis %} a Prince soone wonne with mouing words:

lines.speaker: Hen.
lines.text: By this account then, {% italic: Margaret %} may winne him,

lines.speaker: Hen.
lines.text: For she's a woman to be pittied much:

lines.speaker: Hen.
lines.text: Her sighes will make a batt'ry in his brest,

lines.speaker: Hen.
lines.text: Her teares will pierce into a Marble heart:

lines.speaker: Hen.
lines.text: The Tyger will be milde, whiles she doth mourne;

lines.speaker: Hen.
lines.text: And {% italic: Nero %} will be tainted with remorse,

lines.speaker: Hen.
lines.text: To heare and see her plaints, her Brinish Teares.

lines.speaker: Hen.
lines.text: I, but shee's come to begge, Warwicke to giue:

lines.speaker: Hen.
lines.text: Shee on his left side, crauing ayde for {% italic: Henrie %};

lines.speaker: Hen.
lines.text: He on his right, asking a wife for {% italic: Edward %}.

lines.speaker: Hen.
lines.text: Shee Weepes, and sayes, her {% italic: Henry %} is depos'd:

lines.speaker: Hen.
lines.text: He Smiles, and sayes, his {% italic: Edward %} is instaul'd;

lines.speaker: Hen.
lines.text: That she (poore Wretch) for greefe can speake no more:

lines.speaker: Hen.
lines.text: Whiles Warwicke tels his Title, smooths the Wrong,

lines.speaker: Hen.
lines.text: Inferreth arguments of mighty strength,

lines.speaker: Hen.
lines.text: And in conclusion winnes the King from her,

lines.speaker: Hen.
lines.text: With promise of his Sister, and what else,

lines.speaker: Hen.
lines.text: To strengthen and support King {% italic: Edwards %} place.

lines.speaker: Hen.
lines.text: O {% italic: Margaret %}, thus 'twill be, and thou (poore soule)

lines.speaker: Hen.
lines.text: Art then forsaken, as thou went'st forlorne.

lines.speaker: Hum.
lines.text: Say, what art thou talk'st of Kings & Queens?

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: More then I seeme, and lesse then I was born to:

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: A man at least, for lesse I should not be:

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: And men may talke of Kings, and why not I?

lines.speaker: Hum.
lines.text: I, but thou talk'st, as if thou wer't a King.

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: Why so I am (in Minde) and that's enough.

lines.speaker: Hum.
lines.text: But if thou be a King, where is thy Crowne?

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: My Crowne is in my heart, not on my head:

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: Not deck'd with Diamonds, and Indian stones:

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: Nor to be seene: my Crowne, is call'd Content,

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: A Crowne it is, that sildome Kings enjoy.

lines.speaker: Hum.
lines.text: Well, if you be a King crown'd with Content,

lines.speaker: Hum.
lines.text: Your Crowne Content, and you, must be contented

lines.speaker: Hum.
lines.text: To go along with vs. For (as we thinke)

lines.speaker: Hum.
lines.text: You are the king King {% italic: Edward %} hath depos'd:

lines.speaker: Hum.
lines.text: And we his subiects, sworne in all Allegeance,

lines.speaker: Hum.
lines.text: Will apprehend you, as his Enemie.

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: But did you neuer sweare, and breake an Oath.

lines.speaker: Hum.
lines.text: No, neuer such an Oath, nor will not now.

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: Where did you dwell when I was of England?

lines.speaker: Hum.
lines.text: Heere in this Country, where we now remaine.

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: I was annointed King at nine monthes old,

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: My Father, and my Grandfather were Kings:

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: And you were sworne true Subiects vnto me:

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: And tell me then, haue you not broke your Oathes?

lines.speaker: Sin.
lines.text: No, for we were Subiects, but while you wer king

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: Why? Am I dead? Do I not breath a Man?

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: Ah simple men, you know not what you sweare:

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: Looke, as I blow this Feather from my Face,

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: And as the Ayre blowes it to me againe,

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: Obeying with my winde when I do blow,

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: And yeelding to another, when it blowes,

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: Commanded alwayes by the greater gust:

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: Such is the lightnesse of you, common men.

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: But do not breake your Oathes, for of that sinne,

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: My milde intreatie shall not make you guiltie.

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: Go where you will, the king shall be commanded,

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: And be you kings, command, and Ile obey.

lines.speaker: Sinklo.
lines.text: We are true Subiects to the king,

lines.speaker: Sinklo.
lines.text: King {% italic: Edward %}.

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: So would you be againe to {% italic: Henrie %},

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: If he were seated as king {% italic: Edward %} is.

lines.speaker: Sinklo.
lines.text: We charge you in Gods name & the Kings,

lines.speaker: Sinklo.
lines.text: To go with vs vnto the Officers.

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: In Gods name lead, your Kings name be obeyd,

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: And what God will, that let your King performe,

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: And what he will, I humbly yeeld vnto.

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: Brother of Gloster, at Albons field

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: This Ladyes Husband, Sir {% italic: Richard Grey %}, was slaine,

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: His Land then seiz'd on by the Conqueror,

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: Her suit is now, to repossesse those Lands,

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: Which wee in Iustice cannot well deny,

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: Because in Quarrell of the House of Yorke,

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: The worthy Gentleman did lose his Life.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Your Highnesse shall doe well to graunt her suit:

lines.speaker: Rich.
