lines.speaker: Warw.
lines.text: To make prescription for a Kingdomes worth.

lines.speaker: Oxf.
lines.text: Why {% italic: Warwicke %}, canst thou speak against thy Liege,

lines.speaker: Oxf.
lines.text: Whom thou obeyd'st thirtie and six yeeres,

lines.speaker: Oxf.
lines.text: And not bewray thy Treason with a Blush?

lines.speaker: Warw.
lines.text: Can {% italic: Oxford %}, that did euer sence the right,

lines.speaker: Warw.
lines.text: Now buckler Falsehood with a Pedigree?

lines.speaker: Warw.
lines.text: For shame leaue {% italic: Henry %}, and call {% italic: Edward %} King.

lines.speaker: Oxf.
lines.text: Call him my King, by whose iniurious doome

lines.speaker: Oxf.
lines.text: My elder Brother, the Lord s {% italic: Aubrey Vere %}

lines.speaker: Oxf.
lines.text: Was done to death? and more then so, my Father,

lines.speaker: Oxf.
lines.text: Euen in the downe‑fall of his mellow'd yeeres,

lines.speaker: Oxf.
lines.text: When Nature brought him to the doore of Death?

lines.speaker: Oxf.
lines.text: No {% italic: Warwicke %}, no: while Life vpholds this Arme,

lines.speaker: Oxf.
lines.text: This Arme vpholds the House of {% italic: Lancaster %}.

lines.speaker: Warw.
lines.text: And I the House of {% italic: Yorke %}.

lines.speaker: Lewis.
lines.text: Queene {% italic: Margaret %}, Prince {% italic: Edward %}, and {% italic: Oxford %},

lines.speaker: Lewis.
lines.text: Vouchsafe at our request, to stand aside,

lines.speaker: Lewis.
lines.text: While I vse further conference with {% italic: Warwicke %}.

lines.speaker: Marg.
lines.text: Heauens graunt, that {% italic: Warwickes %} wordes be­

lines.speaker: Lewis.
lines.text: Now {% italic: Warwicke %}, tell me euen vpon thy conscience

lines.speaker: Lewis.
lines.text: Is {% italic: Edward %} your true King? for I were loth

lines.speaker: Lewis.
lines.text: To linke with him, that were not lawfull chosen.

lines.speaker: Warw.
lines.text: Thereon I pawne my Credit, and mine Ho­

lines.speaker: Lewis.
lines.text: But is hee gracious in the Peoples eye?

lines.speaker: Warw.
lines.text: The more, that {% italic: Henry %} was vnfortunate.

lines.speaker: Lewis.
lines.text: Then further: all dissembling set aside,

lines.speaker: Lewis.
lines.text: Tell me for truth, the measure of his Loue

lines.speaker: Lewis.
lines.text: Vnto our Sister {% italic: Bona %}.

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: Such it seemes,

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: As may beseeme a Monarch like himselfe.

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: My selfe haue often heard him say, and sweare,

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: That this his Loue was an externall Plant,

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: Whereof the Root was fixt in Vertues ground,

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: The Leaues and Fruit maintain'd with Beauties Sunne,

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: Exempt from Enuy, but not from Disdaine,

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: Vnlesse the Lady {% italic: Bona %} quit his paine.

lines.speaker: Lewis.
lines.text: Now Sister, let vs heare your firme resolue.

lines.speaker: Bona.
lines.text: Your graunt, or your denyall, shall be mine.

lines.speaker: Bona.
lines.text: Yet I confesse, that often ere this day,

lines.speaker: Bona.
lines.text: When I haue heard your Kings desert recounted,

lines.speaker: Bona.
lines.text: Mine eare hath tempted iudgement to desire.

lines.speaker: Lewis.
lines.text: Then {% italic: Warwicke %}, thus:

lines.speaker: Lewis.
lines.text: Our Sister shall be {% italic: Edwards %}.

lines.speaker: Lewis.
lines.text: And now forthwith shall Articles be drawne,

lines.speaker: Lewis.
lines.text: Touching the Ioynture that your King must make,

lines.speaker: Lewis.
lines.text: Which with her Dowrie shall be counter‑poys'd:

lines.speaker: Lewis.
lines.text: Draw neere, Queene {% italic: Margaret %}, and be a witnesse,

lines.speaker: Lewis.
lines.text: That {% italic: Bona %} shall be Wife to the English King.

lines.speaker: Pr. Edw.
lines.text: To {% italic: Edward %}, but not to the English King.

lines.speaker: Marg.
lines.text: Deceitfull {% italic: Warwicke %}, it was thy deuice,

lines.speaker: Marg.
lines.text: By this alliance to make void my suit:

lines.speaker: Marg.
lines.text: Before thy comming, {% italic: Lewis %} was {% italic: Henries %} friend.

lines.speaker: Lewis.
lines.text: And still is friend to him, and {% italic: Margaret %}.

lines.speaker: Lewis.
lines.text: But if your Title to the Crowne be weake,

lines.speaker: Lewis.
lines.text: As may appeare by {% italic: Edwards %} good successe;

lines.speaker: Lewis.
lines.text: Then 'tis but reason, that I be releas'd

lines.speaker: Lewis.
lines.text: From giuing ayde, which late I promised.

lines.speaker: Lewis.
lines.text: Yet shall you haue all kindnesse at my hand,

lines.speaker: Lewis.
lines.text: That your Estate requires, and mine can yeeld.

lines.speaker: Warw.
lines.text: {% italic: Henry %} now liues in Scotland, at his ease;

lines.speaker: Warw.
lines.text: Where hauing nothing, nothing can he lose.

lines.speaker: Warw.
lines.text: And as for you your selfe (our quondam Queene)

lines.speaker: Warw.
lines.text: You haue a Father able to maintaine you,

lines.speaker: Warw.
lines.text: And better 'twere, you troubled him, then France.

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: Peace impudent, and shamelesse Warwicke,

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: Proud setter vp, and puller downe of Kings,

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: I will not hence, till with my Talke and Teares

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: (Both full of Truth) I make King {% italic: Lewis %} behold

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: Thy slye conueyance, and thy Lords false loue,

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: For both of you are Birds of selfe‑same Feather.

lines.speaker: Lewis.
lines.text: Warwicke, this is some poste to vs, or thee.

lines.speaker: Post.
lines.text: My Lord Ambassador,

lines.speaker: Post.
lines.text: These Letters are for you.

lines.speaker: Post.
lines.text: Sent from your Brother Marquesse {% italic: Montague %}.

lines.speaker: Post.
lines.text: These from our King, vnto your Maiesty.

lines.speaker: Post.
lines.text: And Madam, these for you:

lines.speaker: Post.
lines.text: From whom, I know not.

lines.speaker: Oxf.
lines.text: I like it well, that our faire Queene and Mistris

lines.speaker: Oxf.
lines.text: Smiles at her newes, while {% italic: Warwicke %} frownes at his.

lines.speaker: Prince Ed.
lines.text: Nay marke how {% italic: Lewis %} stampes as he were

lines.speaker: Lew.
lines.text: Warwicke, what are thy Newes ?

lines.speaker: Lew.
lines.text: And yours, faire Queene.

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: Mine such, as fill my heart with vnhop'd ioyes.

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: Mine full of sorrow, and hearts discontent.

lines.speaker: Lew.
lines.text: What? has your King married the Lady {% italic: Grey? %}

lines.speaker: Lew.
lines.text: And now to sooth your Forgery, and his,

lines.speaker: Lew.
lines.text: Sends me a Paper to perswade me Patience?

lines.speaker: Lew.
lines.text: Is this th'Alliance that he seekes with France?

lines.speaker: Lew.
lines.text: Dare he presume to scorne vs in this manner?

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: I told your Maiesty as much before:

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: This proueth {% italic: Edwards %} Loue, and Warwickes honesty.

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: King {% italic: Lewis %}, I heere protest in sight of heauen,

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: And by the hope I haue of heauenly blisse,

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: That I am cleere from this misdeed of {% italic: Edwards %};

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: No more my King, for he dishonors me,

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: But most himselfe, if he could see his shame.

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: Did I forget, that by the House of Yorke

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: My Father came vntimely to his death?

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: Did I let passe th'abuse done to my Neece?

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: Did I impale him with the Regall Crowne ?

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: Did I put {% italic: Henry %} from his Natiue Right?

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: And am I guerdon'd at the last, with Shame?

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: Shame on himselfe, for my Desert is Honor.

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: And to repaire my Honor lost for him,

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: I heere renounce him, and returne to {% italic: Henry %}.

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: My Noble Queene, let former grudges passe,

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: And henceforth, I am thy true Seruitour:

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: I will reuenge his wrong to Lady {% italic: Bona %},

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: And replant {% italic: Henry %} in his former state.

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: Warwicke,

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: These words haue turn'd my Hate, to Loue,

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: And I forgiue, and quite forget old faults,

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: And ioy that thou becom'st King {% italic: Henries %} Friend.

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: So much his Friend, I, his vnfained Friend,

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: That if King {% italic: Lewis %} vouchsafe to furnish vs

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: With some few Bands of chosen Soldiours,

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: Ile vndertake to Land them on our Coast,

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: And force the Tyrant from his seat by Warre.

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: 'Tis not his new‑made Bride shall succour him.

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: And as for {% italic: Clarence %}, as my Letters tell me,

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: Hee's very likely now to fall from him,

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: For matching more for wanton Lust, then Honor,

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: Or then for strength and safety of our Country.

lines.speaker: Bona.
lines.text: Deere Brother, how shall {% italic: Bona %} be reueng'd,

lines.speaker: Bona.
lines.text: But by thy helpe to this distressed Queene?

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: Renowned Prince, how shall Poore {% italic: Henry %} liue,

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: Vnlesse thou rescue him from foule dispaire?

lines.speaker: Bona.
lines.text: My quarrel, and this English Queens, are one.

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: And mine faire Lady {% italic: Bona %}, ioynes with yours.

lines.speaker: Lew.
lines.text: And mine, with hers, and thine, and {% italic: Margarets %}.

lines.speaker: Lew.
lines.text: Therefore, at last, I firmely am resolu'd

lines.speaker: Lew.
lines.text: You shall haue ayde.

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: Let me giue humble thankes for all, at once.

lines.speaker: Lew.
lines.text: Then Englands Messenger, returne in Poste,

lines.speaker: Lew.
lines.text: And tell false {% italic: Edward %}, thy supposed King,

lines.speaker: Lew.
lines.text: That {% italic: Lewis %} of France, is sending ouer Maskers

lines.speaker: Lew.
lines.text: To reuell it with him, and his new Bride.

lines.speaker: Lew.
lines.text: Thou seest what's past, go feare thy King withall.

lines.speaker: Bona.
lines.text: Tell him, in hope hee'l proue a widower shortly,

lines.speaker: Bona.
lines.text: I weare the Willow Garland for his sake.

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: Tell him, my mourning weeds are layde aside,

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: And I am ready to put Armor on.

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: Tell him from me, that he hath done me wrong,

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: And therefore Ile vn‑Crowne him, er't be long.

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: There's thy reward, be gone.

lines.speaker: Lew.
lines.text: But Warwicke,

lines.speaker: Lew.
lines.text: Thou and Oxford, with fiue thousand men

lines.speaker: Lew.
lines.text: Shall crosse the Seas, and bid false {% italic: Edward %} battaile:

lines.speaker: Lew.
lines.text: And as occasion serues, this Noble Queen

lines.speaker: Lew.
lines.text: And Prince, shall follow with a fresh Supply.

lines.speaker: Lew.
lines.text: Yet ere thou go, but answer me one doubt:

lines.speaker: Lew.
lines.text: What Pledge haue we of thy firme Loyalty?

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: This shall assure my constant Loyalty,

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: That if our Queene, and this young Prince agree,

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: Ile ioyne mine eldest daughter, and my Ioy,

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: To him forthwith, in holy Wedlocke bands.

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: Yes, I agree, and thanke you for your Motion.

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: Sonne {% italic: Edward %}, she is Faire and Vertuous,

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: Therefore delay not, giue thy hand to Warwicke,

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: And with thy hand, thy faith irreuocable,

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: That onely Warwickes daughter shall be thine.

lines.speaker: Prin. Ed.
lines.text: Yes, I accept her, for she well deserues it,

lines.speaker: Prin. Ed.
lines.text: And heere to pledge my Vow, I giue my hand.

lines.speaker: Lew.
lines.text: Why stay we now? These soldiers shalbe leuied,

lines.speaker: Lew.
lines.text: And thou Lord Bourbon, our High Admirall

lines.speaker: Lew.
lines.text: Shall waft them ouer with our Royall Fleete.

lines.speaker: Lew.
lines.text: I long till {% italic: Edward %} fall by Warres mischance,

lines.speaker: Lew.
lines.text: For mocking Marriage with a Dame of France.

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: I came from {% italic: Edward %} as Ambassador,

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: But I returne his sworne and mortall Foe:

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: Matter of Marriage was the charge he gaue me,

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: But dreadfull Warre shall answer his demand.

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: Had he none else to make a stale but me?

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: Then none but I, shall turne his Iest to Sorrow.

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: I was the Cheefe that rais'd him to the Crowne,

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: And Ile be Cheefe to bring him downe againe:

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: Not that I pitty {% italic: Henries %} misery,

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: But seeke Reuenge on {% italic: Edwards %} mockery.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Now tell me Brother {% italic: Clarence %}, what thinke you

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Of this new Marriage with the Lady {% italic: Gray %}?

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Hath not our Brother made a worthy choice?

lines.speaker: Cla.
lines.text: Alas, you know, tis farre from hence to France,

lines.speaker: Cla.
lines.text: How could he stay till {% italic: Warwicke %} made returne?

lines.speaker: Som.
lines.text: My Lords, forbeare this talke: heere comes the

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: And his well‑chosen Bride.

lines.speaker: Clarence.
lines.text: I minde to tell him plainly what I thinke.

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: Now Brother of Clarence,

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: How like you our Choyce,

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: That you stand pensiue, as halfe malecontent?

lines.speaker: Clarence.
lines.text: As well as {% italic: Lewis %} of France,

lines.speaker: Clarence.
lines.text: Or the Earle of Warwicke,

lines.speaker: Clarence.
lines.text: Which are so weake of courage, and in iudgement,

lines.speaker: Clarence.
lines.text: That they'le take no offence at our abuse.

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: Suppose they take offence without a cause:

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: They are but {% italic: Lewis %} and {% italic: Warwicke %}, I am {% italic: Edward %},

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: Your King and {% italic: Warwickes %}, and must haue my will.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: And shall haue your will, because our King:

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Yet hastie Marriage seldome proueth well.

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: Yea, Brother {% italic: Richard %}, are you offended too?

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Not I: no:

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: God forbid, that I should wish them seuer'd,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Whom God hath ioyn'd together:

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: I, and 'twere pittie, to sunder them,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: That yoake so well together.

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: Setting your skornes, and your mislike aside,

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: Tell me some reason, why the Lady {% italic: Grey %}

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: Should not become my Wife, and Englands Queene?

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: And you too, {% italic: Somerset %}, and {% italic: Mountague %},

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: Speake freely what you thinke.

lines.speaker: Clarence.
lines.text: Then this is mine opinion:

lines.speaker: Clarence.
lines.text: That King {% italic: Lewis %} becomes your Enemie,

lines.speaker: Clarence.
lines.text: For mocking him about the Marriage

lines.speaker: Clarence.
lines.text: Of the Lady {% italic: Bona %}.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: And {% italic: Warwicke %}, doing what you gaue in charge,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Is now dis‑honored by this new Marriage.

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: What, if both {% italic: Lewis %} and {% italic: Warwick %}, be appeas'd,

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: By such inuention as I can deuise?

lines.speaker: Mount.
lines.text: Yet, to haue ioyn'd with France in such alliance,

lines.speaker: Mount.
lines.text: Would more haue strength'ned this our Commonwealth

lines.speaker: Mount.
lines.text: 'Gainst forraine stormes, then any home‑bred Marriage.

lines.speaker: Hast.
lines.text: Why, knowes not {% italic: Mountague %}, that of it selfe,

lines.speaker: Hast.
lines.text: England is safe, if true within it selfe?

lines.speaker: Mount.
lines.text: But the safer, when 'tis back'd with France.

lines.speaker: Hast.
lines.text: 'Tis better vsing France, then trusting France:

lines.speaker: Hast.
lines.text: Let vs be back'd with God, and with the Seas,

lines.speaker: Hast.
lines.text: Which he hath giu'n for fence impregnable,

lines.speaker: Hast.
lines.text: And with their helpes, onely defend our selues:

lines.speaker: Hast.
lines.text: In them, and in our selues, our safetie lyes.

lines.speaker: Clar.
lines.text: For this one speech, Lord {% italic: Hastings %} well deserues

lines.speaker: Clar.
lines.text: To haue the Heire of the Lord {% italic: Hungerford %}.

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: I, what of that? it was my will, and graunt,

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: And for this once, my Will shall stand for Law.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: And yet me thinks, your Grace hath not done well,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: To giue the Heire and Daughter of Lord {% italic: Scales %}

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Vnto the Brother of your louing Bride;

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Shee better would haue fitted me, or {% italic: Clarence: %}

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: But in your Bride you burie Brotherhood.

lines.speaker: Clar.
lines.text: Or else you would not haue bestow'd the Heire

lines.speaker: Clar.
lines.text: Of the Lord {% italic: Bonuill %} on your new Wiues Sonne,

lines.speaker: Clar.
lines.text: And leaue your Brothers to goe speede elsewhere.

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: Alas, poore {% italic: Clarence: %} is it for a Wife

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: That thou art malecontent ? I will prouide thee.

lines.speaker: Clarence.
lines.text: In chusing for your selfe,

lines.speaker: Clarence.
lines.text: You shew'd your iudgement:

lines.speaker: Clarence.
lines.text: Which being shallow, you shall giue me leaue

lines.speaker: Clarence.
lines.text: To play the Broker in mine owne behalfe;

lines.speaker: Clarence.
lines.text: And to that end, I shortly minde to leaue you.

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: Leaue me, or tarry, {% italic: Edward %} will be King,

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: And not be ty'd vnto his Brothers will.

lines.speaker: Lady Grey.
lines.text: My Lords, before it pleas'd his Maiestie

lines.speaker: Lady Grey.
lines.text: To rayse my state to Title of a Queene,

lines.speaker: Lady Grey.
lines.text: Doe me but right, and you must all confesse,

lines.speaker: Lady Grey.
lines.text: That I was not ignoble of Descent,

lines.speaker: Lady Grey.
lines.text: And meaner then my selfe haue had like fortune.

lines.speaker: Lady Grey.
lines.text: But as this Title honors me and mine,

lines.speaker: Lady Grey.
lines.text: So your dislikes, to whom I would be pleasing,

lines.speaker: Lady Grey.
lines.text: Doth cloud my ioyes with danger, and with sorrow.

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: My Loue, forbeare to fawne vpon their frownes;

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: What danger, or what sorrow can befall thee,

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: So long as {% italic: Edward %} is thy constant friend,

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: And their true Soueraigne, whom they must obey?

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: Nay, whom they shall obey, and loue thee too,

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: Vnlesse they seeke for hatred at my hands:

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: Which if they doe, yet will I keepe thee safe,

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: And they shall feele the vengeance of my wrath.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: I heare, yet say not much, but thinke the more.

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: Now Messenger, what Letters, or what Newes

lines.speaker: Post.
lines.text: My Soueraigne Liege, no Letters, & few words,

lines.speaker: Post.
lines.text: But such, as I (without your speciall pardon)

lines.speaker: Post.
lines.text: Dare not relate.

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: Goe too, wee pardon thee:

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: Therefore, in briefe, tell me their words,

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: As neere as thou canst guesse them.

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: What answer makes King {% italic: Lewis %} vnto our Letters?

lines.speaker: Post.
lines.text: At my depart, these were his very words:

lines.speaker: Post.
lines.text: Goe tell false {% italic: Edward %}, the supposed King,

lines.speaker: Post.
lines.text: That {% italic: Lewis %} of France is sending ouer Maskers,

lines.speaker: Post.
lines.text: To reuell it with him, and his new Bride.

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: Is {% italic: Lewis %} so braue? belike he thinkes me {% italic: Henry %}.

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: But what said Lady {% italic: Bona %} to my Marriage?

lines.speaker: Post.
lines.text: These were her words, vtt'red with mild disdaine:

lines.speaker: Post.
lines.text: Tell him, in hope hee'le proue a Widower shortly,

lines.speaker: Post.
lines.text: Ile weare the Willow Garland for his sake.

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: I blame not her; she could say little lesse:

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: She had the wrong. But what said {% italic: Henries %} Queene?

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: For I haue heard, that she was there in place.

lines.speaker: Post.
lines.text: Tell him (quoth she)

lines.speaker: Post.
lines.text: My mourning Weedes are done,

lines.speaker: Post.
lines.text: And I am readie to put Armour on.

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: Belike she minds to play the Amazon.

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: But what said {% italic: Warwicke %} to these iniuries?

lines.speaker: Post.
lines.text: He, more incens'd against your Maiestie,

lines.speaker: Post.
lines.text: Then all the rest, discharg'd me with these words:

lines.speaker: Post.
lines.text: Tell him from me, that he hath done me wrong,

lines.speaker: Post.
lines.text: And therefore Ile vncrowne him, er't be long.

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: Ha? durst the Traytor breath out so prowd words?

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: Well, I will arme me, being thus fore‑warn'd:

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: They shall haue Warres, and pay for their presumption.

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: But say, is {% italic: Warwicke %} friends with {% italic: Margaret? %}

lines.speaker: Post.
lines.text: I, gracious Soueraigne,

lines.speaker: Post.
lines.text: They are so link'd in friendship,

lines.speaker: Post.
lines.text: That yong Prince {% italic: Edward %} marryes {% italic: Warwicks %} Daughter.

lines.speaker: Clarence.
lines.text: Belike, the elder;

lines.speaker: Clarence.
lines.text: {% italic: Clarence %} will haue the younger.

lines.speaker: Clarence.
lines.text: Now Brother King farewell, and sit you fast,

lines.speaker: Clarence.
lines.text: For I will hence to {% italic: Warwickes %} other Daughter,

lines.speaker: Clarence.
lines.text: That though I want a Kingdome, yet in Marriage

lines.speaker: Clarence.
lines.text: I may not proue inferior to your selfe.

lines.speaker: Clarence.
lines.text: You that loue me, and {% italic: Warwicke %}, follow me.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Not I:

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: My thoughts ayme at a further matter:

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: I stay not for the loue of {% italic: Edward %}, but the Crowne.

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: {% italic: Clarence %} and {% italic: Somerset %} both gone to {% italic: Warwicke %}?

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: Yet am I arm'd against the worst can happen:

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: And haste is needfull in this desp'rate case.

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: {% italic: Pembrooke %} and {% italic: Stafford %}, you in our behalfe.

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: Goe leuie men, and make prepare for Warre;

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: They are alreadie, or quickly will be landed:

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: My selfe in person will straight follow you.

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: But ere I goe, {% italic: Hastings %} and {% italic: Mountague %}

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: Resolue my doubt: you twaine, of all the rest,

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: Are neere to {% italic: Warwicke %}, by his bloud, and by allyance:

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: Tell me, if you loue {% italic: Warwicke %} more then me;

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: If it be so, then both depart to him:

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: I rather wish you foes, then hollow friends.

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: But if you minde to hold your true obedience,

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: Giue me assurance with some friendly Vow,

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: That I may neuer haue you in suspect.

lines.speaker: Mount.
lines.text: So God helpe {% italic: Mountague %}, as hee proues

lines.speaker: Hast.
lines.text: And {% italic: Hastings %}, as hee fauours {% italic: Edwards %} cause.

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: Now Brother {% italic: Richard %}, will you stand by vs?

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: I, in despight of all that shall withstand you.

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: Why so: then am I sure of Victorie.

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: Now therefore let vs hence, and lose no howre,

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: Till wee meet {% italic: Warwicke %}, with his forreine powre.

lines.speaker: Warw.
lines.text: Trust me, my Lord, all hitherto goes well,

lines.speaker: Warw.
lines.text: The common people by numbers swarme to vs.

lines.speaker: Warw.
lines.text: But see where {% italic: Somerset %} and {% italic: Clarence %} comes:

lines.speaker: Warw.
lines.text: Speake suddenly, my Lords, are wee all friends?

lines.speaker: Clar.
lines.text: Feare not that, my Lord.

lines.speaker: Warw.
lines.text: Then gentle {% italic: Clarence %}, welcome vnto {% italic: Warwicke %},

lines.speaker: Warw.
lines.text: And welcome {% italic: Somerset: %} I hold it cowardize,

lines.speaker: Warw.
lines.text: To rest mistrustfull, where a Noble Heart

lines.speaker: Warw.
lines.text: Hath pawn'd an open Hand, in signe of Loue;

lines.speaker: Warw.
lines.text: Else might I thinke, that {% italic: Clarence, Edwards %} Brother,

lines.speaker: Warw.
lines.text: Were but a fained friend to our proceedings:

lines.speaker: Warw.
lines.text: But welcome sweet {% italic: Clarence %}, my Daughter shall be thine.

lines.speaker: Warw.
lines.text: And now, what rests? but in Nights Couerture,

lines.speaker: Warw.
lines.text: Thy Brother being carelessely encamp'd,

lines.speaker: Warw.
lines.text: His Souldiors lurking in the Towne about,

lines.speaker: Warw.
lines.text: And but attended by a simple Guard,

lines.speaker: Warw.
lines.text: Wee may surprize and take him at our pleasure,

lines.speaker: Warw.
lines.text: Our Scouts haue found the aduenture very easie:

lines.speaker: Warw.
lines.text: That as {% italic: Vlysses %}, and stout {% italic: Diomede %},

lines.speaker: Warw.
lines.text: With sleight and manhood stole to {% italic: Rhesus %} Tents,

lines.speaker: Warw.
lines.text: And brought from thence the Thracian fatall Steeds;

lines.speaker: Warw.
lines.text: So wee, well couer'd with the Nights black Mantle,

lines.speaker: Warw.
lines.text: At vnawares may beat downe {% italic: Edwards %} Guard,

lines.speaker: Warw.
lines.text: And seize himselfe: I say not, slaughter him,

lines.speaker: Warw.
lines.text: For I intend but onely to surprize him.

lines.speaker: Warw.
lines.text: You that will follow me to this attempt,

lines.speaker: Warw.
lines.text: Applaud the Name of {% italic: Henry %}, with your Leader.

lines.speaker: Warw.
lines.text: Why then, let's on our way in silent sort,

lines.speaker: Warw.
lines.text: For {% italic: Warwicke %} and his friends, God and Saint {% italic: George %}.

lines.speaker: 1. Watch.
lines.text: Come on my Masters, each man take his stand,

lines.speaker: 1. Watch.
lines.text: The King by this, is set him downe to sleepe.

lines.speaker: 2. Watch.
lines.text: What, will he not to Bed?

lines.speaker: 1. Watch.
lines.text: Why, no: for he hath made a solemne Vow,

lines.speaker: 1. Watch.
lines.text: Neuer to lye and take his naturall Rest,

lines.speaker: 1. Watch.
lines.text: Till {% italic: Warwicke %}, or himselfe, be quite supprest.

lines.speaker: 2. Watch.
lines.text: To morrow then belike shall be the day,

lines.speaker: 2. Watch.
lines.text: If {% italic: Warwicke %} be so neere as men report.

lines.speaker: 3. Watch.
lines.text: But say, I pray, what Noble man is that,

lines.speaker: 3. Watch.
lines.text: That with the King here resteth in his Tent?

lines.speaker: 1. Watch.
lines.text: 'Tis the Lord {% italic: Hastings %}, the Kings chiefest

lines.speaker: 3. Watch.
lines.text: O, is it so? but why commands the King,

lines.speaker: 3. Watch.
lines.text: That his chiefe followers lodge in Townes about him,

lines.speaker: 3. Watch.
lines.text: While he himselfe keepes in the cold field?

lines.speaker: 2. Watch.
lines.text: 'Tis the more honour, because more dange­

lines.speaker: 3. Watch.
lines.text: I, but giue me worship, and quietnesse,

lines.speaker: 3. Watch.
lines.text: I like it better then a dangerous honor.

lines.speaker: 3. Watch.
lines.text: If {% italic: Warwicke %} knew in what estate he stands,

lines.speaker: 3. Watch.
lines.text: 'Tis to be doubted he would waken him.

lines.speaker: 1. Watch.
lines.text: Vnlesse our Halberds did shut vp his pas­

lines.speaker: 2. Watch.
lines.text: I: wherefore else guard we his Royall Tent,

lines.speaker: 2. Watch.
lines.text: But to defend his Person from Night‑foes?

lines.speaker: Warw.
lines.text: This is his Tent, and see where stand his Guard;

lines.speaker: Warw.
lines.text: Courage my Masters: Honor now, or neuer:

lines.speaker: Warw.
lines.text: But follow me, and {% italic: Edward %} shall be ours.

lines.speaker: 1. Watch.
lines.text: Who goes there?

lines.speaker: 2. Watch.
lines.text: Stay, or thou dyest.

lines.speaker: Som.
lines.text: What are they that flye there?

lines.speaker: Warw.
lines.text: {% italic: Richard %} and {% italic: Hastings: %} let them goe, heere is

lines.speaker: K. Edw.
lines.text: The Duke?

lines.speaker: K. Edw.
lines.text: Why {% italic: Warwicke %}, when wee parted,

lines.speaker: K. Edw.
lines.text: Thou call'dst me King.

lines.speaker: Warw.
lines.text: I, but the case is alter'd.

lines.speaker: Warw.
lines.text: When you disgrac'd me in my Embassade,

lines.speaker: Warw.
lines.text: Then I degraded you from being King,

lines.speaker: Warw.
lines.text: And come now to create you Duke of Yorke.

lines.speaker: Warw.
lines.text: Alas, how should you gouerne any Kingdome,

lines.speaker: Warw.
lines.text: That know not how to vse Embassadors,

lines.speaker: Warw.
lines.text: Nor how to be contented with one Wife,

lines.speaker: Warw.
lines.text: Nor how to vse your Brothers Brotherly,

lines.speaker: Warw.
lines.text: Nor how to studie for the Peoples Welfare,

lines.speaker: Warw.
lines.text: Nor how to shrowd your selfe from Enemies?

lines.speaker: K. Edw.
lines.text: Yea, Brother of Clarence,

lines.speaker: K. Edw.
lines.text: Art thou here too?

lines.speaker: K. Edw.
lines.text: Nay then I see, that {% italic: Edward %} needs must downe.

lines.speaker: K. Edw.
lines.text: Yet {% italic: Warwicke %}, in despight of all mischance,

lines.speaker: K. Edw.
lines.text: Of thee thy selfe, and all thy Complices,

lines.speaker: K. Edw.
lines.text: {% italic: Edward %} will always beare himselfe as King:

lines.speaker: K. Edw.
lines.text: Though Fortunes mallice ouerthrow my State,

lines.speaker: K. Edw.
lines.text: My minde exceedes the compasse of her Wheele.

lines.speaker: Warw.
lines.text: Then for his minde, be {% italic: Edward %} Englands King,

lines.speaker: Warw.
lines.text: But {% italic: Henry %} now shall weare the English Crowne,

lines.speaker: Warw.
lines.text: And be true King indeede: thou but the shadow.

lines.speaker: Warw.
lines.text: My Lord of Somerset, at my request,

lines.speaker: Warw.
lines.text: See that forthwith Duke {% italic: Edward %} be conuey'd

lines.speaker: Warw.
lines.text: Vnto my Brother Arch‑Bishop of Yorke:

lines.speaker: Warw.
lines.text: When I haue fought with {% italic: Pembrooke %}, and his fellowes,

lines.speaker: Warw.
lines.text: Ile follow you, and tell what answer

lines.speaker: Warw.
lines.text: {% italic: Lewis %} and the Lady {% italic: Bona %} send to him.

lines.speaker: Warw.
lines.text: Now for a‑while farewell good Duke of Yorke.

lines.speaker: K. Ed.
lines.text: What Fates impose, that men must needs abide;

lines.speaker: K. Ed.
lines.text: It boots not to resist both winde and tide.

lines.speaker: Oxf.
lines.text: What now remaines my Lords for vs to do,

lines.speaker: Oxf.
lines.text: But march to London with our Soldiers?

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: I, that's the first thing that we haue to do,

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: To free King {% italic: Henry %} from imprisonment,

lines.speaker: War.
lines.text: And see him seated in the Regall Throne.

lines.speaker: Riu.
lines.text: Madam, what makes you in this sodain change?

lines.speaker: Gray.
lines.text: Why Brother {% italic: Riuers %}, are you yet to learne

lines.speaker: Gray.
lines.text: What late misfortune is befalne King {% italic: Edward %}?

lines.speaker: Riu.
lines.text: What losse of some pitcht battell

lines.speaker: Riu.
lines.text: Against {% italic: Warwicke %}?

lines.speaker: Gray.
lines.text: No, but the losse of his owne Royall person.

lines.speaker: Riu.
lines.text: Then is my Soueraigne slaine?

lines.speaker: Gray.
lines.text: I almost slaine, for he is taken prisoner,

lines.speaker: Gray.
lines.text: Either betrayd by falshood of his Guard,

lines.speaker: Gray.
lines.text: Or by his Foe surpriz'd at vnawares:

lines.speaker: Gray.
lines.text: And as I further haue to vnderstand,

lines.speaker: Gray.
lines.text: Is new committed to the Bishop of Yorke,

lines.speaker: Gray.
lines.text: Fell Warwickes Brother, and by that our Foe.

lines.speaker: Riu.
lines.text: These Newes I must confesse are full of greefe,

lines.speaker: Riu.
lines.text: Yet gracious Madam, beare it as you may,

lines.speaker: Riu.
lines.text: Warwicke may loose, that now hath wonne the day.

lines.speaker: Gray.
lines.text: Till then, faire hope must hinder liues decay:

lines.speaker: Gray.
lines.text: And I the rather waine me from dispaire

lines.speaker: Gray.
lines.text: For loue of {% italic: Edwards %} Off‑spring in my wombe:

lines.speaker: Gray.
lines.text: This is it that makes me bridle passion,

lines.speaker: Gray.
lines.text: And beare with Mildnesse my misfortunes crosse:

lines.speaker: Gray.
lines.text: I, I, for this I draw in many a teare,

lines.speaker: Gray.
lines.text: And stop the rising of blood‑sucking sighes,

lines.speaker: Gray.
lines.text: Least with my sighes or teares, I blast or drowne

lines.speaker: Gray.
lines.text: King {% italic: Edwards %} Fruite, true heyre to th'English Crowne.

lines.speaker: Riu.
lines.text: But Madam,

lines.speaker: Riu.
lines.text: Where is Warwicke then become?

lines.speaker: Gray.
lines.text: I am inform'd that he comes towards London,

lines.speaker: Gray.
lines.text: To set the Crowne once more on {% italic: Henries %} head,

lines.speaker: Gray.
lines.text: Guesse thou the rest, King {% italic: Edwards %} Friends must downe.

lines.speaker: Gray.
lines.text: But to preuent the Tyrants violence,

lines.speaker: Gray.
lines.text: (For trust not him that hath once broken Faith)

lines.speaker: Gray.
lines.text: Ile hence forthwith vnto the Sanctuary,

lines.speaker: Gray.
lines.text: To saue (at least) the heire of {% italic: Edwards %} right:

lines.speaker: Gray.
lines.text: There shall I rest secure from force and fraud:

lines.speaker: Gray.
lines.text: Come therefore let vs flye, while we may flye,

lines.speaker: Gray.
lines.text: If Warwicke take vs, we are sure to dye.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Now my Lord {% italic: Hastings %}, and Sir {% italic: William Stanley %}

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Leaue off to wonder why I drew you hither,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Into this cheefest Thicket of the Parke.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Thus stand the case: you know our King, my Brother,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Is prisoner to the Bishop here, at whose hands

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: He hath good vsage, and great liberty,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: And often but attended with weake guard,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Come hunting this way to disport himselfe.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: I haue aduertis'd him by secret meanes,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: That if about this houre he make this way,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Vnder the colour of his vsuall game,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: He shall heere finde his Friends with Horse and Men,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: To set him free from his Captiuitie.

lines.speaker: Huntsman.
lines.text: This way my Lord,

lines.speaker: Huntsman.
lines.text: For this way lies the Game.

lines.speaker: King Edw.
lines.text: Nay this way man,

lines.speaker: King Edw.
lines.text: See where the Huntsmen stand.

lines.speaker: King Edw.
lines.text: Now Brother of Gloster, Lord Hastings, and the rest,

lines.speaker: King Edw.
lines.text: Stand you thus close to steale the Bishops Deere?

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Brother, the time and case, requireth hast,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Your horse stands ready at the Parke‑corner.

lines.speaker: King Ed.
lines.text: But whether shall we then?

lines.speaker: Hast.
lines.text: To Lyn my Lord,

lines.speaker: Hast.
lines.text: And shipt from thence to Flanders.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Wel guest beleeue me, for that was my meaning

lines.speaker: K. Ed.
lines.text: {% italic: Stanley %}, I will requite thy forwardnesse.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: But wherefore stay we? 'tis no time to talke.

lines.speaker: K. Ed.
lines.text: Huntsman, what say'st thou?

lines.speaker: K. Ed.
lines.text: Wilt thou go along ?

lines.speaker: Hunts.
lines.text: Better do so, then tarry and be hang'd.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Come then away, lets ha no more adoo.

lines.speaker: K. Ed.
lines.text: Bishop farwell,

lines.speaker: K. Ed.
lines.text: Sheeld thee from {% italic: Warwickes %} frowne,

lines.speaker: K. Ed.
lines.text: And pray that I may re‑possesse the Crowne.

lines.speaker: K. Hen.
lines.text: Lieutenant, now that God and Friends

lines.speaker: K. Hen.
lines.text: Haue shaken {% italic: Edward %} from the Regall seate,

lines.speaker: K. Hen.
lines.text: And turn'd my captiue state to libertie,

lines.speaker: K. Hen.
lines.text: My feare to hope, my sorrowes vnto ioyes,

lines.speaker: K. Hen.
lines.text: At our enlargement what are thy due Fees?

lines.speaker: Lieu.
lines.text: Subiects may challenge nothing of their Sou'rains

lines.speaker: Lieu.
lines.text: But, if an humble prayer may preuaile,

lines.speaker: Lieu.
lines.text: I then craue pardon of your Maiestie.

lines.speaker: K. Hen.
lines.text: For what, Lieutenant? For well vsing me?

lines.speaker: K. Hen.
lines.text: Nay, be thou sure, Ile well requite thy kindnesse.

lines.speaker: K. Hen.
lines.text: For that it made my imprisonment, a pleasure:

lines.speaker: K. Hen.
lines.text: I, such a pleasure, as incaged Birds

lines.speaker: K. Hen.
lines.text: Conceiue; when after many moody Thoughts,

lines.speaker: K. Hen.
lines.text: At last, by Notes of Houshold harmonie,

lines.speaker: K. Hen.
lines.text: They quite forget their losse of Libertie.

lines.speaker: K. Hen.
lines.text: But {% italic: Warwicke %}, after God, thou set'st me free,

lines.speaker: K. Hen.
lines.text: And chiefely therefore, I thanke God, and thee,

lines.speaker: K. Hen.
lines.text: He was the Author, thou the Instrument.

lines.speaker: K. Hen.
lines.text: Therefore that I may conquer Fortunes spight,

lines.speaker: K. Hen.
lines.text: By liuing low, where Fortune cannot hurt me,

lines.speaker: K. Hen.
lines.text: And that the people of this blessed Land

lines.speaker: K. Hen.
lines.text: May not be punisht with my thwarting starres,

lines.speaker: K. Hen.
lines.text: {% italic: Warwicke %}, although my Head still weare the Crowne,

lines.speaker: K. Hen.
lines.text: I here resigne my Gouernment to thee,

lines.speaker: K. Hen.
lines.text: For thou art fortunate in all thy deeds.

lines.speaker: Warw.
lines.text: Your Grace hath still beene fam'd for vertuous,

lines.speaker: Warw.
lines.text: And now may seeme as wise as vertuous,

lines.speaker: Warw.
lines.text: By spying and auoiding Fortunes malice,

lines.speaker: Warw.
lines.text: For few men rightly temper with the Starres:

lines.speaker: Warw.
lines.text: Yet in this one thing let me blame your Grace,

lines.speaker: Warw.
lines.text: For chusing me, when {% italic: Clarence %} is in place.

lines.speaker: Clar.
lines.text: No {% italic: Warwicke %}, thou art worthy of the sway,

lines.speaker: Clar.
lines.text: To whom the Heau'ns in thy Natiuitie,

lines.speaker: Clar.
lines.text: Adiudg'd an Oliue Branch, and Lawrell Crowne,

lines.speaker: Clar.
lines.text: As likely to be blest in Peace and Warre:

lines.speaker: Clar.
lines.text: And therefore I yeeld thee my free consent.

lines.speaker: Warw.
lines.text: And I chuse {% italic: Clarence %} onely for Protector.

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: {% italic: Warwick %} and {% italic: Clarence %}, giue me both your Hands:

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: Now ioyne your Hands, & with your Hands your Hearts,

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: That no dissention hinder Gouernment:

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: I make you both Protectors of this Land,

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: While I my selfe will lead a priuate Life,

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: And in deuotion spend my latter dayes,

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: To sinnes rebuke, and my Creators prayse.

lines.speaker: Warw.
lines.text: What answeres {% italic: Clarence %} to his Soueraignes ?

lines.speaker: Clar.
lines.text: That he consents, if {% italic: Warwicke %} yeeld consent,

lines.speaker: Clar.
lines.text: For on thy fortune I repose my selfe.

lines.speaker: Warw.
lines.text: Why then, though loth, yet must I be content:

lines.speaker: Warw.
lines.text: Wee'le yoake together, like a double shadow

lines.speaker: Warw.
lines.text: To {% italic: Henries %} Body, and supply his place;

lines.speaker: Warw.
lines.text: I meane, in bearing weight of Gouernment,

lines.speaker: Warw.
lines.text: While he enioyes the Honor, and his ease.

lines.speaker: Warw.
lines.text: And {% italic: Clarence %}, now then it is more then needfull,

lines.speaker: Warw.
lines.text: Forthwith that {% italic: Edward %} be pronounc'd a Traytor,

lines.speaker: Warw.
lines.text: And all his Lands and Goods confiscate.

lines.speaker: Clar.
lines.text: What else? and that Succession be determined.

lines.speaker: Warw.
lines.text: I, therein {% italic: Clarence %} shall not want his part.

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: But with the first, of all your chiefe affaires,

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: Let me entreat (for I command no more)

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: That {% italic: Margaret %} your Queene, and my Sonne {% italic: Edward %},

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: Be sent for, to returne from France with speed:

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: For till I see them here, by doubtfull feare,

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: My ioy of libertie is halfe eclips'd.

lines.speaker: Clar.
lines.text: It shall bee done, my Soueraigne, with all

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: My Lord of Somerset, what Youth is that,

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: Of whom you seeme to haue so tender care?

lines.speaker: Somers.
lines.text: My Liege, it is young {% italic: Henry %}, Earle of Rich­

lines.text: And set vp {% italic: Lancaster %}. Why, trowest thou, {% italic: Warwicke %},

lines.speaker: Clar.
lines.text: That {% italic: Clarence %} is so harsh, so blunt, vnnaturall,

lines.speaker: Clar.
lines.text: To bend the fatall Instruments of Warre

lines.speaker: Clar.
lines.text: Against his Brother, and his lawfull King.

lines.speaker: Clar.
lines.text: Perhaps thou wilt obiect my holy Oath:

lines.speaker: Clar.
lines.text: To keepe that Oath, were more impietie,

lines.speaker: Clar.
lines.text: Then {% italic: Iephah %}, when he sacrific'd his Daughter.

lines.speaker: Clar.
lines.text: I am so sorry for my Trespas made,

lines.speaker: Clar.
lines.text: That to deserue well at my Brothers hands,

lines.speaker: Clar.
lines.text: I here proclayme my selfe thy mortall foe:

lines.speaker: Clar.
lines.text: With resolution, wheresoe're I meet thee,

lines.speaker: Clar.
lines.text: (As I will meet thee, if thou stirre abroad)

lines.speaker: Clar.
lines.text: To plague thee, for thy foule mis‑leading me.

lines.speaker: Clar.
lines.text: And so, prowd‑hearted {% italic: Warwicke %}, I defie thee,

lines.speaker: Clar.
lines.text: And to my Brother turne my blushing Cheekes.

lines.speaker: Clar.
lines.text: Pardon me {% italic: Edward %}, I will make amends:

lines.speaker: Clar.
lines.text: And {% italic: Richard %}, doe not frowne vpon my faults,

lines.speaker: Clar.
lines.text: For I will henceforth be no more vnconstant.

lines.speaker: Edw.
lines.text: Now welcome more, and ten times more belou'd,

lines.speaker: Edw.
lines.text: Then if thou neuer hadst deseru'd our hate.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Welcome good {% italic: Clarence %}, this is Brother‑like.

lines.speaker: Warw.
lines.text: Oh passing Traytor, periur'd and vniust.

lines.speaker: Edw.
lines.text: What {% italic: Warwicke %},

lines.speaker: Edw.
lines.text: Wilt thou leaue the Towne, and fight?

lines.speaker: Edw.
lines.text: Or shall we beat the Stones about thine Eares?

lines.speaker: Warw.
lines.text: Alas, I am not coop'd here for defence:

lines.speaker: Warw.
lines.text: I will away towards Barnet presently,

lines.speaker: Warw.
lines.text: And bid thee Battaile, {% italic: Edward %}, if thou dar'st.

lines.speaker: Edw.
lines.text: Yes {% italic: Warwicke, Edward %} dares, and leads the way:

lines.speaker: Edw.
lines.text: Lords to the field: Saint {% italic: George %}, and Victorie.

lines.speaker: Edw.
lines.text: So, lye thou there: dye thou, and dye our feare,

lines.speaker: Edw.
lines.text: For {% italic: Warwicke %} was a Bugge that fear'd vs all.

lines.speaker: Edw.
lines.text: Now {% italic: Mountague %} sit fast, I seeke for thee,

lines.speaker: Edw.
lines.text: That {% italic: Warwickes %} Bones may keepe thine companie.

lines.speaker: Warw.
lines.text: Ah, who is nigh? come to me, friend, or foe,

lines.speaker: Warw.
lines.text: And tell me who is Victor, {% italic: Yorke %}, or {% italic: Warwicke? %}

lines.speaker: Warw.
lines.text: Why aske I that? my mangled body shewes,

lines.speaker: Warw.
lines.text: My blood, my want of strength, my sicke heart shewes,

lines.speaker: Warw.
lines.text: That I must yeeld my body to the Earth,

lines.speaker: Warw.
lines.text: And by my fall, the conquest to my foe.

lines.speaker: Warw.
lines.text: Thus yeelds the Cedar to the Axes edge,

lines.speaker: Warw.
lines.text: Whose Armes gaue shelter to the Princely Eagle,

lines.speaker: Warw.
lines.text: Vnder whose shade the ramping Lyon slept,

lines.speaker: Warw.
lines.text: Whose top‑branch ouer‑peer'd {% italic: Ioues %} spreading Tree,

lines.speaker: Warw.
lines.text: And kept low Shrubs from Winters pow'rfull Winde.

lines.speaker: Warw.
lines.text: These Eyes, that now are dim'd with Deaths black Veyle,

lines.speaker: Warw.
lines.text: Haue beene as piercing as the Mid‑day Sunne,

lines.speaker: Warw.
lines.text: To search the secret Treasons of the World:

lines.speaker: Warw.
lines.text: The Wrinckles in my Browes, now fill'd with blood,

lines.speaker: Warw.
lines.text: Were lik'ned oft to Kingly Sepulchers:

lines.speaker: Warw.
lines.text: For who liu'd King, but I could digge his Graue?

lines.speaker: Warw.
lines.text: And who durst smile, when {% italic: Warwicke %} bent his Brow?

lines.speaker: Warw.
lines.text: Loe, now my Glory smear'd in dust and blood.

lines.speaker: Warw.
lines.text: My Parkes, my Walkes, my Mannors that I had,

lines.speaker: Warw.
lines.text: Euen now forsake me, and of all my Lands,

lines.speaker: Warw.
lines.text: Is nothing left me, but my bodies length.

lines.speaker: Warw.
lines.text: Why, what is Pompe, Rule, Reigne, but Earth and Dust?

lines.speaker: Warw.
lines.text: And liue we how we can, yet dye we must.

lines.speaker: Som.
lines.text: Ah {% italic: Warwicke, Warwicke %}, wert thou as we are,

lines.speaker: Som.
lines.text: We might recouer all our Losse againe:

lines.speaker: Som.
lines.text: The Queene from France hath brought a puissant power.

lines.speaker: Som.
lines.text: Euen now we heard the newes: ah, could'st thou flye.

lines.speaker: Warw.
lines.text: Why then I would not flye. Ah {% italic: Mountague %},

lines.speaker: Warw.
lines.text: If thou be there, sweet Brother, take my Hand,

lines.speaker: Warw.
lines.text: And with thy Lippes keepe in my Soule a while.

lines.speaker: Warw.
lines.text: Thou lou'st me not: for, Brother, if thou didst,

lines.speaker: Warw.
lines.text: Thy teares would wash this cold congealed blood,

lines.speaker: Warw.
lines.text: That glewes my Lippes, and will not let me speake.

lines.speaker: Warw.
lines.text: Come quickly {% italic: Mountague %}, or I am dead.

lines.speaker: Som.
lines.text: Ah {% italic: Warwicke, Mountague %} hath breath'd his last,

lines.speaker: Som.
lines.text: And to the latest gaspe, cry'd out for {% italic: Warwicke: %}

lines.speaker: Som.
lines.text: And said, Commend me to my valiant Brother.

lines.speaker: Som.
lines.text: And more he would haue said, and more he spoke,

lines.speaker: Som.
lines.text: Which sounded like a Cannon in a Vault,

lines.speaker: Som.
lines.text: That mought not be distinguisht: but at last,

lines.speaker: Som.
lines.text: I well might heare, deliuered with a groane,

lines.speaker: Som.
lines.text: Oh farewell {% italic: Warwicke %}.

lines.speaker: Warw.
lines.text: Sweet rest his Soule:

lines.speaker: Warw.
lines.text: Flye Lords, and saue your selues,

lines.speaker: Warw.
lines.text: For {% italic: Warwicke %} bids you all farewell, to meet in Heauen.

lines.speaker: Oxf.
lines.text: Away, away, to meet the Queenes great power.

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: Thus farre our fortune keepes an vpward course,

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: And we are grac'd with wreaths of Victorie:

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: But in the midst of this bright‑shining Day;

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: I spy a black suspicious threatning Cloud,

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: That will encounter with our glorious Sunne,

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: Ere he attaine his easefull Westerne Bed:

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: I meane, my Lords, those powers that the Queene

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: Hath rays'd in Gallia, haue arriued our Coast,

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: And, as we heare, march on to fight with vs.

lines.speaker: Clar.
lines.text: A little gale will soone disperse that Cloud,

lines.speaker: Clar.
lines.text: And blow it to the Source from whence it came,

lines.speaker: Clar.
lines.text: Thy very Beames will dry those Vapours vp,

lines.speaker: Clar.
lines.text: For euery Cloud engenders not a Storme.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: The Queene is valued thirtie thousand strong,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: And {% italic: Somerset %}, with {% italic: Oxford %}, fled to her:

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: If she haue time to breathe, be well assur'd

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Her faction will be full as strong as ours.

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: We are aduertis'd by our louing friends,

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: That they doe hold their course toward Tewksbury.

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: We hauing now the best at Barnet field,

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: Will thither straight, for willingnesse rids way,

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: And as we march, our strength will be augmented:

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: In euery Countie as we goe along,

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: Strike vp the Drumme, cry courage, and away.

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Great Lords, wise men ne'r sit and waile their losse,

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: But chearely seeke how to redresse their harmes.

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: What though the Mast be now blowne ouer‑boord,

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: The Cable broke, the holding‑Anchor lost,

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: And halfe our Saylors swallow'd in the flood?

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Yet liues our Pilot still. Is't meet, that hee

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Should leaue the Helme, and like a fearefull Lad,

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: With tearefull Eyes adde Water to the Sea,

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: And giue more strength to that which hath too much,

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Whiles in his moane, the Ship splits on the Rock,

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Which Industrie and Courage might haue sau'd?

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Ah what a shame, ah what a fault were this.

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Say {% italic: Warwicke %} was our Anchor: what of that ?

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: And {% italic: Mountague %} our Top‑Mast: what of him?

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Our slaught'red friends, the Tackles: what of these?

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Why is not {% italic: Oxford %} here, another Anchor?

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: And {% italic: Somerset %}, another goodly Mast?

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: The friends of France our Shrowds and Tacklings?

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: And though vnskilfull, why not {% italic: Ned %} and I,

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: For once allow'd the skilfull Pilots Charge?

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: We will not from the Helme, to sit and weepe,

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: But keepe our Course (though the rough Winde say no)

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: From Shelues and Rocks, that threaten vs with Wrack.

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: As good to chide the Waues, as speake them faire.

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: And what is {% italic: Edward %}, but a ruthlesse Sea?

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: What {% italic: Clarence %}, but a Quick‑sand of Deceit?

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: And {% italic: Richard %}, but a raged fatall Rocke?

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: All these, the Enemies to our poore Barke.

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Say you can swim, alas 'tis but a while:

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Tread on the Sand, why there you quickly sinke,

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Bestride the Rock, the Tyde will wash you off,

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Or else you famish, that's a three‑fold Death.

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: This speake I (Lords) to let you vnderstand,

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: If case some one of you would flye from vs,

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: That there's no hop'd‑for Mercy with the Brothers,

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: More then with ruthlesse Waues, with Sands and Rocks.

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Why courage then, what cannot be auoided,

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: 'Twere childish weakenesse to lament, or feare.

lines.speaker: Prince.
lines.text: Me thinkes a Woman of this valiant Spirit,

lines.speaker: Prince.
lines.text: Should, if a Coward heard her speake these words,

lines.speaker: Prince.
lines.text: Infuse his Breast with Magnanimitie,

lines.speaker: Prince.
lines.text: And make him, naked, foyle a man at Armes.

lines.speaker: Prince.
lines.text: I speake not this, as doubting any here:

lines.speaker: Prince.
lines.text: For did I but suspect a fearefull man,

lines.speaker: Prince.
lines.text: He should haue leaue to goe away betimes,

lines.speaker: Prince.
lines.text: Least in our need he might infect another,

lines.speaker: Prince.
lines.text: And make him of like spirit to himselfe.

lines.speaker: Prince.
lines.text: If any such be here, as God forbid,

lines.speaker: Prince.
lines.text: Let him depart, before we neede his helpe.

lines.speaker: Oxf.
lines.text: Women and Children of so high a courage,

lines.speaker: Oxf.
lines.text: And Warriors faint, why 'twere perpetuall shame.

lines.speaker: Oxf.
lines.text: Oh braue young Prince: thy famous Grandfather

lines.speaker: Oxf.
lines.text: Doth liue againe in thee; long may'st thou liue,

lines.speaker: Oxf.
lines.text: To beare his Image, and renew his Glories.

lines.speaker: Som.
lines.text: And he that will not fight for such a hope,

lines.speaker: Som.
lines.text: Goe home to Bed, and like the Owle by day,

lines.speaker: Som.
lines.text: If he arise, be mock'd and wondred at.

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Thankes gentle {% italic: Somerset %}, sweet {% italic: Oxford %} thankes.

lines.speaker: Prince.
lines.text: And take his thankes, that yet hath nothing

lines.speaker: Mess.
lines.text: Prepare you Lords, for {% italic: Edward %} is at hand,

lines.speaker: Mess.
lines.text: Readie to fight: therefore be resolute.

lines.speaker: Oxf.
lines.text: I thought no lesse: it is his Policie,

lines.speaker: Oxf.
lines.text: To haste thus fast, to finde vs vnprouided.

lines.speaker: Som.
lines.text: But hee's deceiu'd, we are in readinesse.

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: This cheares my heart, to see your forwardnesse.

lines.speaker: Oxf.
lines.text: Here pitch our Battaile, hence we will not budge.

lines.speaker: Edw.
lines.text: Braue followers, yonder stands the thornie Wood,

lines.speaker: Edw.
lines.text: Which by the Heauens assistance, and your strength,

lines.speaker: Edw.
lines.text: Must by the Roots be hew'ne vp yet ere Night.

lines.speaker: Edw.
lines.text: I need not adde more fuell to your fire,

lines.speaker: Edw.
lines.text: For well I wot, ye blaze, to burne them out:

lines.speaker: Edw.
lines.text: Giue signall to the fight, and to it Lords.

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Lords, Knights, and Gentlemen, what I should say,

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: My teares gaine‑say: for euery word I speake,

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Ye see I drinke the water of my eye.

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Therefore no more but this: {% italic: Henry %} your Soueraigne

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Is Prisoner to the Foe, his State vsurp'd,

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: His Realme a slaughter‑house, his Subiects slaine,

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: His Statutes cancell'd, and his Treasure spent:

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: And yonder is the Wolfe, that makes this spoyle.

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: You fight in Iustice: then in Gods Name, Lords,

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Be valiant, and giue signall to the fight.

lines.speaker: Edw.
lines.text: Now here a period of tumultuous Broyles.

lines.speaker: Edw.
lines.text: Away with {% italic: Oxford %} to Hames Castle straight:

lines.speaker: Edw.
lines.text: For {% italic: Somerset %}, off with his guiltie Head.

lines.speaker: Edw.
lines.text: Goe beare them hence, I will not heare them speake.

lines.speaker: Oxf.
lines.text: For my part, Ile not trouble thee with words.

lines.speaker: Som.
lines.text: Nor I, but stoupe with patience to my fortune.

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: So part we sadly in this troublous World,

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: To meet with Ioy in sweet Ierusalem.

lines.speaker: Edw.
lines.text: Is Proclamation made, That who finds {% italic: Edward %},

lines.speaker: Edw.
lines.text: Shall haue a high Reward, and he his Life?

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: It is, and loe where youthfull {% italic: Edward %} comes.

lines.speaker: Edw.
lines.text: Bring forth the Gallant, let vs heare him speake.

lines.speaker: Edw.
lines.text: What? can so young a Thorne begin to prick ?

lines.speaker: Edw.
lines.text: {% italic: Edward %}, what satisfaction canst thou make,

lines.speaker: Edw.
lines.text: For bearing Armes, for stirring vp my Subiects,

lines.speaker: Edw.
lines.text: And all the trouble thou hast turn'd me to?

lines.speaker: Prince.
lines.text: Speake like a Subiect, prowd ambitious {% italic: Yorke %}.

lines.speaker: Prince.
lines.text: Suppose that I am now my Fathers Mouth,

lines.speaker: Prince.
lines.text: Resigne thy Chayre, and where I stand, kneele thou,

lines.speaker: Prince.
lines.text: Whil'st I propose the selfe‑same words to thee,

lines.speaker: Prince.
lines.text: Which (Traytor) thou would'st haue me answer to.

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Ah, that thy Father had beene so resolu'd.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: That you might still haue worne the Petticoat,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: And ne're haue stolne the Breech from {% italic: Lancaster %}.

lines.speaker: Prince.
lines.text: Let {% italic: Æsop %} fable in a Winters Night,

lines.speaker: Prince.
lines.text: His Currish Riddles sorts not with this place.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: By Heauen, Brat, Ile plague ye for that word.

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: I, thou wast borne to be a plague to men.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: For Gods sake, take away this Captiue Scold.

lines.speaker: Prince.
lines.text: Nay, take away this scolding Crooke‑backe,

lines.speaker: Edw.
lines.text: Peace wilfull Boy, or I will charme your tongue.

lines.speaker: Clar.
lines.text: Vntutor'd Lad, thou art too malapert.

lines.speaker: Prince.
lines.text: I know my dutie, you are all vndutifull:

lines.speaker: Prince.
lines.text: Lasciuious {% italic: Edward %}, and thou periur'd {% italic: George %},

lines.speaker: Prince.
lines.text: And thou mis‑shapen {% italic: Dicke %}, I tell ye all,

lines.speaker: Prince.
lines.text: I am your better, Traytors as ye are,

lines.speaker: Prince.
lines.text: And thou vsurp'st my Fathers right and mine.

lines.speaker: Edw.
lines.text: Take that, the likenesse of this Rayler here.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Sprawl'st thou? take that, to end thy agonie.

lines.speaker: Clar.
lines.text: And ther's for twitting me with periurie.

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Oh, kill me too.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Marry, and shall.

lines.speaker: Edw.
lines.text: Hold, {% italic: Richard %}, hold, for we haue done too much.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Why should shee liue, to fill the World with

lines.speaker: Edw.
lines.text: What? doth shee swowne? vse meanes for her

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: {% italic: Clarence %} excuse me to the King my Brother:

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Ile hence to London on a serious matter,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Ere ye come there, be sure to heare some newes.

lines.speaker: Cla.
lines.text: What? what ?

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Tower, the Tower.

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Oh {% italic: Ned %}, sweet {% italic: Ned %}, speake to thy Mother Boy.

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Can'st thou not speake? O Traitors, Murtherers!

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: They that stabb'd {% italic: Cæsar %}, shed no blood at all:

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Did not offend, nor were not worthy Blame,

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: If this foule deed were by, to equall it.

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: He was a Man; this (in respect) a Childe,

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: And Men, ne're spend their fury on a Childe.

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: What's worse then Murtherer, that I may name it?

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: No, no, my heart will burst, and if I speake,

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: And I will speake, that so my heart may burst.

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Butchers and Villaine, bloudy Caniballes,

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: How sweet a Plant haue you vntimely cropt:

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: You haue no children (Butchers) if you had,

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: The thought of them would haue stirr'd vp remorse,

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: But if you euer chance to haue a Childe,

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Looke in his youth to haue him so cut off.

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: As deathsmen you haue rid this sweet yong Prince.

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: Away with her, go beare her hence perforce.

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Nay, neuer beare me hence, dispatch me heere:

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Here sheath thy Sword, Ile pardon thee my death:

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: What? wilt thou not? Then {% italic: Clarence %} do it thou.

lines.speaker: Cla.
lines.text: By heauen, I will not do thee so much ease.

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Good {% italic: Clarence %} do: Sweet {% italic: Clarence %} do thou do it.

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Did'st thou not heare me sweare I would not do it?

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: I, but thou vsest to forsweare thy selfe.

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: 'Twas Sin before, but now 'tis Charity.

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: What wilt y u not? Where is that diuels butcher {% italic: Richard %}?

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Hard fauor'd {% italic: Richard %}? {% italic: Richard %}, where art thou?

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Thou art not heere; Murther is thy Almes‑deed:

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Petitioners for Blood, thou ne're put'st backe.

lines.speaker: Ed.
lines.text: Away I say, I charge ye beare her hence.

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: So come to you, and yours, as to this Prince.

lines.speaker: Ed.
lines.text: Where's {% italic: Richard %} gone.

lines.speaker: Cla.
lines.text: To London all in post, and as I guesse,

lines.speaker: Cla.
lines.text: To make a bloody Supper in the Tower.

lines.speaker: Ed.
lines.text: He's sodaine if a thing comes in his head.

lines.speaker: Ed.
lines.text: Now march we hence, discharge the common sort

lines.speaker: Ed.
lines.text: With Pay and Thankes, and let's away to London,

lines.speaker: Ed.
lines.text: And see our gentle Queene how well she fares,

lines.speaker: Ed.
lines.text: By this (I hope) she hath a Sonne for me.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Good day, my Lord, what at your Booke so

lines.speaker: Hen.
lines.text: I my good Lord: my Lord I should say rather,

lines.speaker: Hen.
lines.text: Tis sinne to flatter, Good was little better:

lines.speaker: Hen.
lines.text: 'Good Gloster and good Deuill, were alike,

lines.speaker: Hen.
lines.text: And both preposterous: therefore, not Good Lord.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Sirra, leaue vs to our selues, we must conferre.

lines.speaker: Hen.
lines.text: So flies the wreaklesse shepherd from Wolfe:

lines.speaker: Hen.
lines.text: So first the harmlesse Sheepe doth yeeld his Fleece,

lines.speaker: Hen.
lines.text: And next his Throate, vnto the Butchers Knife.

lines.speaker: Hen.
lines.text: What Scene of death hath {% italic: Rossius %} now to Acte ?

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Suspition alwayes haunts the guilty minde,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: The Theefe doth feare each bush an Officer,

lines.speaker: Hen.
lines.text: The Bird that hath bin limed in a bush,

lines.speaker: Hen.
lines.text: With trembling wings misdoubteth euery bush;

lines.speaker: Hen.
lines.text: And I the haplesse Male to one sweet Bird,

lines.speaker: Hen.
lines.text: Haue now the fatall Obiect in my eye,

lines.speaker: Hen.
lines.text: Where my poore yong was lim'd, was caught, and kill'd.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Why what a peeuish Foole was that of Creet,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: That taught his Sonne the office of a Fowle,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: And yet for all his wings, the Foole was drown'd.

lines.speaker: Hen.
lines.text: I {% italic: Dedaius %}, my poore Boy {% italic: Icarus %},

lines.speaker: Hen.
lines.text: Thy Father {% italic: Minos %}, that deni'de our course,

lines.speaker: Hen.
lines.text: The Sunne that sear'd the wings of my sweet Boy.

lines.speaker: Hen.
lines.text: Thy Brother {% italic: Edward %}, and thy Selfe, the Sea

lines.speaker: Hen.
lines.text: Whose enuious Gulfe did swallow vp his life:

lines.speaker: Hen.
lines.text: Ah, kill me with thy Weapon, not with words,

lines.speaker: Hen.
lines.text: My brest can better brooke thy Daggers point,

lines.speaker: Hen.
lines.text: Then can my eares that Tragicke History.

lines.speaker: Hen.
lines.text: But wherefore dost thou come? Is't for my Life?

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Think'st thou I am an Executioner?

lines.speaker: Hen.
lines.text: A Persecutor I am sure thou art,

lines.speaker: Hen.
lines.text: If murthering Innocents be Executing,

lines.speaker: Hen.
lines.text: Why then thou art an Executioner.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Thy Son I kill'd for his presumption.

lines.speaker: Hen.
lines.text: Hadst thou bin kill'd, when first y u didst presume,

lines.speaker: Hen.
lines.text: Thou had'st not liu'd to kill a Sonne of mine:

lines.speaker: Hen.
lines.text: And thus I prophesie, that many a thousand,

lines.speaker: Hen.
lines.text: Which now mistrust no parcell of my feare,

lines.speaker: Hen.
lines.text: And many an old mans sighe, and many a Widdowes,

lines.speaker: Hen.
lines.text: And many an Orphans water‑standing‑eye,

lines.speaker: Hen.
lines.text: Men for their Sonnes, Wiues for their Husbands,

lines.speaker: Hen.
lines.text: Orphans, for their Parents timeles death,

lines.speaker: Hen.
lines.text: Shall rue the houre that euer thou was't borne.

lines.speaker: Hen.
lines.text: The Owle shriek'd at thy birth, an euill signe,

lines.speaker: Hen.
lines.text: The Night‑Crow cry'de, aboding lucklesse time,

lines.speaker: Hen.
lines.text: Dogs howl'd, and hideous Tempest shook down Trees:

lines.speaker: Hen.
lines.text: The Rauen rook'd her on the Chimnies top,

lines.speaker: Hen.
lines.text: And chatt'ring Pies in dismall Discords sung:

lines.speaker: Hen.
lines.text: Thy Mother felt more then a Mothers paine,

lines.speaker: Hen.
lines.text: And yet brought forth lesse then a Mothers hope,

lines.speaker: Hen.
lines.text: To wit, an indigested and deformed lumpe,

lines.speaker: Hen.
lines.text: Not like the fruit of such a goodly Tree.

lines.speaker: Hen.
lines.text: Teeth had'st thou in thy head, when thou was't borne,

lines.speaker: Hen.
lines.text: To signifie, thou cam'st to bite the world;

lines.speaker: Hen.
lines.text: And if the rest be true, which I haue heard,

lines.speaker: Hen.
lines.text: Thou cam'st⸺

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Ile heare no more:

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Dye Prophet in thy speech,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: For this (among'st the rest) was I ordain'd.

lines.speaker: Hen.
lines.text: I, and for much more slaughter after this,

lines.speaker: Hen.
lines.text: O God forgiue my sinnes, and pardon thee.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: What? will the aspiring blood of Lancaster

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Sinke in the ground? I thought it would haue mounted.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: See how my sword weepes for the poore Kings death.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: O may such purple teares be alway shed

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: From those that wish the downfall of our house.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: If any sparke of Life be yet remaining,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Downe, downe to hell, and say I sent thee thither.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: I that haue neyther pitty, loue, nor feare,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Indeed 'tis true that {% italic: Henrie %} told me of:

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: For I haue often heard my Mother say,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: I came into the world with my Legges forward.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Had I not reason (thinke ye) to make hast,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: And seeke their Ruine, that vsurp'd our Right?

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: The Midwife wonder'd, and the Women cri'de

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: O Iesus blesse vs, he is borne with teeth,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: And so I was, which plainly signified,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: That I should snarle, and bite, and play the dogge:

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Then since the Heauens haue shap'd my Body so,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Let Hell make crook'd my Minde to answer it.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: I haue no Brother, I am like no Brother:

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: And this world [Loue] which Gray‑beards call Diuine,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Be resident in men like one another,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: And not in me: I am my selfe alone.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: {% italic: Clarence %} beware, thou keept'st me from the Light,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: But I will sort a pitchy day for thee:

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: For I will buzze abroad such Prophesies,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: That {% italic: Edward %} shall be fearefull of his life,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: And then to purge his feare, Ile be thy death.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: King {% italic: Henry %}, and the Prince his Son are gone,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: {% italic: Clarence %} thy turne is next, and then the rest,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Counting my selfe but bad, till I be best.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Ile throw thy body in another roome,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: And Triumph {% italic: Henry %}, in thy day of Doome.

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: Once more we sit in Englands Royall Throne,

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: Re‑purchac'd with the Blood of Enemies:

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: What valiant Foe‑men, like to Autumnes Corne,

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: Haue we mow'd downe in tops of all their pride?

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: Three Dukes of Somerset, threefold Renowne,

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: For hardy and vndoubted Champions:

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: Two {% italic: Cliffords %}, as the Father and the Sonne,

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: And two Northumberlands: two brauer men,

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: Ne're spurr'd their Coursers at the Trumpets sound.

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: With them, the two braue Beares, {% italic: Warwick %} & {% italic: Montague %},

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: That in their Chaines fetter'd the Kingly Lyon,

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: And made the Forrest tremble when they roar'd.

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: Thus haue we swept Suspition from our Seate,

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: And made our Footstoole of Security.

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: Come hither {% italic: Besse %}, and let me kisse my Boy:

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: Yong {% italic: Ned %}, for thee, thine Vnckles, and my selfe,

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: Haue in our Armors watcht the Winters night,

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: Went all afoote in Summers scalding heate,

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: That thou might'st repossesse the Crowne in peace,

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: And of our Labours thou shalt reape the gaine.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Ile blast his Haruest, if your head were laid,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: For yet I am not look'd on in the world.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: This shoulder was ordain'd so thicke, to heaue,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: And heaue it shall some waight, or breake my backe,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Worke thou the way, and that shalt execute.

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: {% italic: Clarence %} and {% italic: Gloster %}, loue my louely Queene,

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: And kis your Princely Nephew Brothers both.

lines.speaker: Cla.
lines.text: The duty that I owe vnto your Maiesty,

lines.speaker: Cla.
lines.text: I Seale vpon the lips of this sweet Babe.

lines.speaker: Cla.
lines.text: Thanke Noble {% italic: Clarence %}, worthy brother thanks.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: And that I loue the tree whence y u sprang'st:

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Witnesse the louing kisse I giue the Fruite,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: To say the truth, so {% italic: Iudas %} kist his master,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: And cried all haile, when as he meant all harme.

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: Now am I seated as my soule delights,

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: Hauing my Countries peace, and Brothers loues.

lines.speaker: Cla.
lines.text: What will your Grace haue done with {% italic: Margaret %},

lines.speaker: Cla.
lines.text: {% italic: Reynard %} her Father, to the King of France

lines.speaker: Cla.
lines.text: Hath pawn'd the Sicils and Ieruselem,

lines.speaker: Cla.
lines.text: And hither haue they sent it for her ransome.

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: Away with her, and waft her hence to France:

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: And now what rests, but that we spend the time

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: With stately Triumphes, mirthfull Comicke shewes,

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: Such as befits the pleasure of the Court.

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: Sound Drums and Trumpets, farwell sowre annoy,

lines.speaker: King.
lines.text: For heere I hope begins our lasting ioy.
